reviewText:
Honestly, the best game of its kind.

It has some of the wittiest and most amusing story lines ,dark and mature mixed with tragedy that will take you by surprise.
Beautiful visual design, great mix of colors and nicely put together levels that will remind you of Tim Burton's films.
Voice acting & dialogues are excellent as you would come to expect with Tim Schafer produced games.
Fun combat & platforming mechanics, they serve their purpose but are nothing ground breaking and some of the segments can overstay their welcome slightly.
One part i found was annoying was that you have to grind for money to purchase an item to progress further, which interrupts the pacing somewhat.

All in all a great title which is sadly overlooked by people. Highly recommend to any one who likes FUN.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Psychonauts
Original Release: 2005
Genre Tags: Adventure; RPG; Platformer; Lighthearted; Psychedelic
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-25 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamers
REVIEWPsychonauts is a quirky and imaginative action-adventure game that is an absolute riot.  It is an aging specimen, but it will forever hold a status as a highly enjoyable “cult classic.”  If it has piqued your interest, then I suggest you take a complimentary cup of Kool-Aid and join the cult… you won’t regret it.

Psychonauts excels at many things.  The story, the characters, and the writing are all top-notch and well-executed.  The scenes and developments throughout the campaign are quite amusing and should keep you thoroughly entertained.  The many different characters are all interesting in their own way.  They are all splendidly eccentric and unique, if not also reminiscent of typical Saturday-morning-cartoon archetypes.  And, importantly, the voice acting is mostly decent and sufficiently holds everything else together… although it does falter slightly, on occasion.

Providing setting for the narrative is a very inspired and diverse gameworld that is quite atmospheric.  The graphics used are undeniably dated and are only increasingly falling farther behind the curve; however the developers did an outstanding job of matching the environments and atmosphere to the overall soul of the game.  There is a mixture of lighthearted, noir, cartoonish, and psychedelic ambiances which really diversifies the experience as you play through the campaign.   You may not be awed by the scenery like in modern games, but you can still easily appreciate the effort that was put into the creation of the gameworld.

Of course, the intriguing narrative and captivating atmosphere would be for naught if the gameplay wasn’t enjoyable.  Luckily, Psychonauts is quite fun to play.  There is a pleasant mixture of combat situations and puzzle-solving that you would expect from a game like this.  Situations can be approached by experimentation with various abilities and skills, which you unlock as you progress through the campaign.  Also, the various levels will introduce different dynamics to keep you on your toes.  There are also a ton of collectibles and many achievements to keep you busy, if you are into that kind of thing.

Psychonauts can easily appeal to a wide and diverse audience.  The tone is fairly childish, but has many adult themes.  It is also a pretty easy/casual experience, so there shouldn’t be any skill issues.  It takes approximately 14 to 22 hours to complete, depending on if you strive for achievements or not.  If you like 3D action-adventure platformers, I would say this is a pretty safe bet for you.  It is also a good bet for anyone who may be interested in “seeing what the fuss is about,” as you will probably find it enjoyable once given a try.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Personally this is my favorite Double Fine game. Although it is about nine years old it still holds up as a good game with an interesting art style. Unlike most games built as an atempt at photorealism, the extremely cartoonish graphics and garish colour palette still looks good almost a decade after release. As all games from Tim Schafer the writing is magnificent, the voice acting is well done and the characters always have something important or hilarious to say. The setting of a Summer camp for Psychics not only influences the plot and gameplay but the dialogues actually sound like something children at summer camp would be saying, except that they are about the outlandish topics involved with a world surrounded by psychic weirdness. The gameplay is devided up into two sections, the overworld with some, but not much combat, sidequests, the one shop in the game, and most of the colorful non-essential dialogue, and the insides of the various character's minds. These minds serve as the various levels of the game, each with the same basic controlls but slightly different gameplay. The Meat Circus level is all about fast paced platforming, whilst Lungfishopolis is completely based on the combat system, and the Milkman level(BEST LEVEL EVER) is an old school inventory adventure puzzle mixed with a fever dream X-Files Plot. Throughout the game you gain psy powers that are used in combat and level navigation, some work as a long range attack with the need to collect ammo, and there is a bouncy ball/parachute power that makes platforming much more difficult and interesting.

Now that i have sufficiently gushed about all the things i freaking love about this game it is time to get realistic and talk about the flaws. Most of these flaws have to do with the fact that this was Double Fine's first attempt at an action game. the combat can be a bit annoying with enemy spamming getting overdone at times, that being said most of the basic enemies are too easy to dispatch and clearing the room becomes simply a chore without much actual difficulty. The controlls are somewhat soft and the platforming would be vastly improved by tighter controlls to allow for fine tuned navigation. and if you watch a let's play you can see that the dificulty scale starts off low but when it does ramp up it does so without telling you and later levels,(Milkman,Meat Circus) can become frustrating and take forever to get past, not allways from dificulty of combat or platforming but in the milkman level if you do not know what you are doing it can be almost impossible to figure some of the puzzles out organically.

All that being said these flaws are really not as bad as it sounds. the increased difficulty lends less to frustraton and more to angry inspiration to just beat this next level and prove that you are better than the game. and for the milkman, a quick glance at a gameFAQ can help if you get too badlt stuck, enough people have been frustrated by the level to have wonderfull walkthroughs made to relieve the tension. in the end the story and experience is so good it makes up for any akwardness in gameplay. 8/10, This game is a love it or hate it, and i love it, fantastic but not even close to perfect.

reviewText:
Psychonauts has to be one the greatest Adventure/Platformers of our time, it succeeds in achieving the best aspects of the genre. The controls are tight allowing for great platforming and visually still looks better than most games today. The Steam version of Psychonauts is brilliant, I have not experienced a single bug and it supports HD.

The exploration this game offers is top-notch, you get to explore a large camp littered with clever secrets and challenges along with some of the most insane levels. The combat is entertaining, especially since you get decent upgrades and new powers as you go along, allowing you to form more strategies so it never feels like a boring slogfest.

The art direction of Psychonauts is unlike any other game and is vibrant and unique, you have to wonder what the devs were on when making some of the characters and the sound/soundtrack do their job pretty well. The way this game progresses in terms of difficulty and design is persistent and can get fairly challenging later on in the game. The dialogue is extremely well done adding a lot of life to some of the strangest looking characters in video gaming. The game features a dark/twisted humour which adds to the hilarity of the situations you encounter.

This game gets much better the further you get, the levels get much more abstract and crazier, theres a few here which are total masterpieces and the plot is surprisingly deep for a game of this nature and extremely entertaining.

The amount of imagination put into this game is amazing, the art direction is it's own, the characters are brilliant, the level design is solid, the combat and platforming are tight, the atmosphere is effective, the humour is hilarious as hell and never feels like they tried hard to make it that way, so it doesn't feel forced like many other games that try achieve a comical effect and is loaded with charm, there really is nothing negative about this game.

To get this on Steam is a no brainer as it's an incredibly solid experience that should be experienced by anyone who appreciates Adventure and platforming games and timeless classics. Squirrels are liars.

reviewText:
Psychonauts is like a book with a weird cover. It's a game worth getting into though, even if your eyes might not agree with the art design. Once I got past my nitpicking, I finally gave it the shot it so very deserved. Psychonauts is a 3D platformer meets an adventure game and honestly, I had no idea about the former. As with all platformers, you'll die plenty from falling, which is partly due to a fixed camera and partly cos you suck. Then there are a couple of areas that just aren't very forgiving, but it's nothing you can't overcome. I'd say the difficulty level is just right for this sort of game, apart from the initally daunting and almost sadistic Meat Circus.

It's funny, charming and fun to explore. Finding collectibles is made enjoyable, but you'll have to look out for a Point of No Return, otherwise you won't get 100%. The music from Milla's Dance Party is still in my head, a level that reminded me of the club mission in DmC Devil May Cry. I doubt Ninja Theory were influenced by Psychonauts, these games being such opposites, nevertheless I found it amusing.

First Double Fine/Tim Schafer game now under my belt and I'll be checking out more from them. If it weren't for the massive development budgets we have right now, we'd see more cool games like these. Games like No One Lives Forever 3, which I'm still rooting for.

reviewText: My previous review of this game did not do it justice since I felt it deserved better than that - I'd like to elaborate a bit further on why I love this game ever so much as one of the best innovative games/platformers of all time. Growing up with 2D and 3D platformers like Mario, Crash & Spyro I could easily adapt to the platforming of the game. The platforming itself is solid enough but the actual combat in the game, during times like Boss Battles, can be dodgy as heck if you don't have a controller in handy -- Usually because of several different buttons needed to lock-on enemies and attack or alternatively dodge incoming attacks. You have the option of changing the keys to fit a play-style suitable for yourself, but I still find it frustrating at best namely due to the several important commands required. Here's my advice: Play the game with a controller as it'll make gameplay a bit smoother. So, what makes the game exceptional? Well, first of all it's the premise. The setting is a summer school camp for psychics. The game is brought to us by none other than the master of adventure games, Tim Schäfer (Monkey Island, Grim Fandango, Day of the Tentacle), whose characteristic sense of humor certainly blooms in Psychonauts. One of the long running concepts of Schäfer's style usually juxtaposes a rather mundane situation in a fantastical setting; Such as what you'd expect if Tim Burton & David Lynch teamed up for an all-wacky-superstar tag team line up movie. Which is just as well because creator Tim Schäfer has now acquired his very own Johnny Depp, in form of Jack Black, although he's absent from this game. But I digress - We play as Raz, who's chosen to flee from the circus as opposed to joining it, because being a Psychonaut is a lot more fulfilling than the circus obviously. As he gets accepted into the fold of Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp he soon finds himself in the middle of a strange conspiracy, where the brains of the camp's inhabitants mysteriously vanish which leads to the game's funniest moments. The caricatures that show up in the game are so incredibly diverse and... weird? They are truly fascinating as you get to DIG your way inside their subconscious minds to discover their true hidden feelings. Essentially, Schäfer came up with the idea of Inception before... well Inception. This is the unique part of the game - The environments, atmosphere and overall feel of the inner & deepest thoughts of the camp and local areas inhabitants's minds.\n\nLet me sum up some of the fascinating characters. We have a mad dentist who harvest brains, a talking fish whose thoughts involves a sequence where you become a giant Godzilla monster terrorizing a society of talking fish, a mentally ill security guard who's lost in the mindset of a crazy pyromaniac-milkman, Napoleon Bonaparte and his dimwit descendant, An aspiring musical starlet whose cruel mother's treatment of her and eventual suicide has caused her to develop a case of bipolar disorder, a government agent who disguises himself as a housewife by brandishing a rolling pin while talking disjointedly about pies etc. These are the kind of characters you can expect alongside the campers themselves and the local counselors, whom all are very well rounded and have their own personalities. Usually they are defined by interacting with them around the camp or examining the local signs and written letters, to provide character depth. Lastly, I found myself jamming to the game's cool blues-inspired guitar stringing soundtrack. All in all It's seemingly -- Well done. If you love a good platformer, with some dodgy gameplay at times, while every now and then laughing your ♥♥♥ off and maybe, just maybe, find yourself sympathizing with some of the loonies, as you uncover their hidden feelings. Then look no further than Psychonauts! :)

reviewText:
This is easily my favourite Double Fine game, and that's saying a lot.
At its core this is a third person action adventure platform title, but such a dry description really does not do it justice.
It is happiness and nostalgia distilled into a quirky game about getting into people's minds, literally.

No generic fire level, ice level, jungle level.
Let's visits MINDS.

The mind of a war veteran.
The mind of a painter obsessed with bullfighting.
The mind of a faded actress.
THE MIND OF A SEA MONSTER.

A great story, a great cast, a great WORLD created for you to explore and discover.
Yes, the game has some balance issues, but most of these have been patched out for the Steam release (especially difficulty balancing in the last world).
It's a great game that I totally recommend.

reviewText: Be warned that this is an early-2000s 3d platformer and it really shows- annoying collect-a-thons and all. A controller is recommended if you have access to one- the keyboard controls work but can be a little wonky at times. Some very difficult platforming throughout brings these niggles to light and can be frustrating.\n\nWhere Psychonauts shines instead is in the hugely imaginative (literally!) world and cast of characters, who play the role of both plot progression and game world. Raz's psychic abilities allow him to enter the minds of those who let him in, in order to arrange their thoughts and solve their problems for them- learning their secrets in the meanwhile. Battle Napoleon in a giant game of Risk, help the Milkman defeat the evil girl scouts, and maybe even help Raz confront his childhood fears. Erik Wolpaw, who would later join Valve to write the Portal and Team Fortress series, lends his talents to these characters and ensures they'll leave a big impression on you. If you can forgive the difficulties with the gameplay, the humour on display here is wholly worth it.

reviewText:
First off I'm gonna tell you one thing, buy this game, and then I'll explain why you should. This game is absolutely fantastic. It's fun, it's got a great story, great characters, and hilarious (if not somewhat cheesy) dialogue.

The story is quite interesting, but it's actually really enhanced by the characters. Double Fine did an excellent job of giving every single character (yes even the minor ones) a sense of actual human personality. A 10 year old boy who's running away from the circus to become a psychic agent, a sarcastic girl with the ability to talk to plants and takes no BS from anyone, a timid, socially awkward boy who was told to go to the camp because he kept blowing up people's heads with his mind, and a plethora more of quirky characters really make the game world and gameplay twice as fun and hilarious.

However, another thing that Double Fine did that really gave the game some depth is the subtly. If you pay close attention to each character and their dialogue, memory vaults, and figments, you can find out some surprisingly....dark things about them. Even the main character, Razputin, mentions some pretty awful things that happened to him and his family as a child. But these little things add even more character to them, it makes them feel like they could be actual people because who hasn't had bad experiences or trauma in their lives? For a lot of the young campers, how they hint at these really tragic events is very child-like of them, like how an actual kid who can't quite comprehend those kinds of things would describe or talk about them.

(You can see that I love the characters in this game right?)

Moving on, the combat system is a boatload of fun, with cool abilities that are decently balanced with the gameplay. You can levitate and shoot psychic blasts of energy at your enemies, light almost every living thing on fire, and a bunch more cool things that are required to progress through different levels of the game. Speaking of the game levels, they're coloful and vary from each person's mind you enter, with different bosses and NPCs as well as the variety of different objects and missions that really tell you about the personality of the person's mentality.

However, there does tend to be a bit of vagueness in certain levels where I'd get stuck because there was no clear objective or direction to what I was trying to do. At times it was more frustrating than other levels and if you've ever heard of the infamous last level of this game, the difficulty curve just spikes suddenly with how ridiculously hard and unforgiving it can be (and this version on Steam is the easier version of it!). But nonetheless, it kept me playing the game in a raging I'm going to beat this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level so help me" kind of way.

I will say if you're a person who goes for 100% completion or achievements
date: good luck to you. There's hundreds of these things in the game called figments (like figments of one's imagination) and in some levels they're placed in ridiculously hard to find places. I'm not a person who really cares for those things as much so it never bothered me
recommended: but I can definately see how it would irritate some people who either really hate collecting.\n\nBut aside from those little nitpicks and some level frustrations
hoursPlayed: I absolutely adore this game (and am currently restarting it) and would reccommend it to as many people as possible so Double Fine can come out with a sequel for it already!"

reviewText:
Short version: 88%The cute (but dated) puzzle platformer surface of Psychonauts hides a game teeming with ideas, imagination, and great design choices (plus a not too great control scheme). A game that is worthy of all the praises it got in the past years.

Long version:When Tim Schafer started his own company, Double Fine, in 2001, he was mostly known as the somewhat eccentric designer behind the greatest LucasArts adventures. So when their first title, Psychonauts, was finally released in 2005, it was a surprise to see it commercially fail despite the great reviews.
Although the game eventually gained the following it deserves, it is easy to understand the initial troubles: on the surface, it looks like a typical early 2000s 3D puzzle platformer with 90s kids’ movie stereotype characters drawn as Nickelodeon figures. It took years to finally understand that its greatness lies under the hood.

For starters, there is the plot. Initially, it seems like a summer camp movie about kids who have psychic powers, but as the story goes on, we learn that this movie was apparently directed by Tim Burton, as it slowly turns into a (kid-friendly) nightmare world for our brave protagonist, the somewhat clichéd sassy tough kid Rasputin.

This change in atmosphere is anything but subtle, as the game world moves from a somewhat serene campground to a creepy island asylum. Both of these serve mostly as an overworld that ties together the actual levels, all set in the mindscape, the psyche of certain characters.
These levels are the main reason behind the late-coming success of Psychonauts. Each offers something brand new game mechanic, ranging from simple platforming to almost point ‘n’ click levels of story-driven puzzle solving. They delve deep in the minds of a character, utilising this to its full extent to tell us an interesting, often bittersweet tale, showing us the full capabilities of the storywriting strength Double Fine could deliver.

reviewText: Psychonauts is a 3D action-platformer game originally released on Xbox and Windows in 2005. This game is probably one of the most creative and artful games ever made. In this game, you are a character named Razputin and you need to travel through people's brains in order to solve their problems and whatnot. Each brain (world) is completely different and can be pretty weird. A world takes 30 minutes to 1 hour to complete most of the time, more if you're wasting your time somewhere or trying to solve a puzzle (yes, there are a few puzzles, but they aren't very difficult and give you hints all the time). The game itself isn't super long, you can finish it within 20 hours, probably around 5 if you're replaying the game (it took me 17 hours). You also get upgrades in your journey which let you use special powers (levitation, shooting fire, etc.)\n\nThis game is gold. It has great writing and some bizarre humour, excellent voice acting, beautiful environments, good character design, and an awesome soundtrack. On the negative side, the camera can get annoying sometimes and the story continuity kinda drops near the end of the game. Other than that, it's a game that you should definitely try (you can also get in on Xbox Live or the new Mac version) and that is worth every penny. I honestly wish this game got a sequel though. Awesome game, totally recommend to absolutely anyone.

The game offers a classic platformer in a beautiful and unique visual style, that quickly goes from calm and peaceful to dark and gloomy. Initially the story starts off very much aimed towards children, but as the game progresses it becomes more about immaturity than childishness, and during certain parts of the game you might even find yourself wondering Who is this game actually geared towards?!" reviewText:
Psychonauts is a high quality cult classic that I believe is still a beautiful game today. The characters are funny and the plotline features some bizarre plot twists that are rather enjoyable and will keep you hooked on the game! Most importantly, the setting of Psychonauts is very atmospheric and absorbing, pulling you into the vast landscapes of Whispering Rock's Psychic Summer camp to the depths of anonymous minds, beating down personal demons and obscure personas while doing so. Plus, the soundtrack is amazing and memorable.

If you ever want take a break from the MMO world or simply sit down and relax with a quality, single-player adventure game, Psychonauts shouldn't be missed!

reviewText:
I have grown weary of 3D Platformers.
Over the years, I simply got bored of them.
Have heard of Psychonauts before, but left it aside, assuming it was the same as the rest.

Eyeballing it in my Games List, I decided to give it a shot.

2 weeks later, I'm here, writing this review.

Psychonauts essentially changes everything that a 3D Platform should be, then adds in several cups of the Schafer Salt for good measure.

The game is easier to play now, thanks to the recently added (rudimentory, but sufficient) Xbox 360 controller support.

But is it worth the asking price of US$10?
Very Much yes. Even more so if its below the base price.

I only disliked one level of the game, the very last level (from what I've read, I am not alone), yet the rest of the game I absolutely loved.
The game does not end story-wise and so it is dependant on the sequel, which as of writing this it has not been release yet.

In the Double Fine Catalog, Psychonauts is in the short list of favourite games from the Developer.

reviewText:
Very fun platformer!

Graphics still hold up due to a cartoony look and every level is a different and fun experience. The writing is fantastic and has many laugh out loud moments. The game will keep you busy and interested for at least 10+ hours. My only gripes are the collecto-thon type gameplay did wear a little bit thin by the end. I have always been a big fan of games that have you collecting items, such as Banjo Kazooie, but collecting all of the items in this game is a chore, especially the holograms. Some items, such as the collectable brains, yield different story elements and are interesting. Completing the game will probably add on at least another 5-10 hours of gameplay, all be it repititive and mundane gameplay.

TL;DR Very good writing and creative level. Collecting items grows repetitive, especially if trying to attain 100%. Very good game to pick up on sale.
8/10

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun, and despite being nearly 10 years old, it still holds up really well and plays great. Most of the game is fun and not frustrating (except for the second to last section of the entire game, right before the final boss; try not to punch your screen there ;) ). This may look like a kids game and may even be meant to be a kids game, but I think anyone of any age who enjoys gaming will have fun with this.

The only negatives are mainly due to its age: low resolution cut-scenes are ugly, yeah the graphics and character models are a bit blocky, the invisible walls you encounter don't seem to conform to the shape of the environment, etc. And that second to last bit of the final level just before the final boss will be an exercise in frustration and anger management. But really, none of these things are bad enough to be a dealbreaker in this game.

Worth getting at its usual price; absolute no-brainer when on sale. :)

reviewText:
Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer, but it still delivers an experience that feels wholly original in every aspect of its execution.

Psychonauts is a quirky, offbeat game set in a special summer camp for clairvoyant kids, in which a group of psychic children end up in a wacky adventure filled with brain-stealing hijinks, psychic secret agents, and a little romance on top of everything else. It's rooted in the sorts of 3D platforming sensibilities we've all come to know over the years. But there's a SPIN to the game--its psychic theme--which adds some cool puzzle-solving to the usual platform-jumping and swinging associated with the genre. Psychonauts also bears the unmistakable mark of designer Tim Schafer (known for classic adventure games Grim Fandango, Full Throttle, and Day of the Tentacle), thanks to a hilarious array of peculiar characters and a story that never fails to entertain. Psychonauts doesn't reinvent the platformer, but it still delivers an experience that feels wholly original in every aspect of its execution.

It took four years and two publishers, but Psychonauts is finally here, and no worse for the wear, it seems.
The heart and soul of Psychonauts is Razputin--or, Raz, for short--a big-headed, goggle-sporting psychic prodigy who sneaks his way into a mysterious summer camp that happens to be a training ground for the titular psychonauts, a group of psychic secret agents. Raz, it seems, has run away from his home in the circus and wants to become a psychonaut himself. Grudgingly, the counselors of the camp accept Raz into the group (albeit only for a day, until his father can come get him and take him home). However, it doesn't take long for strange things to start happening around camp. Raz, as well as other children, find that they're suffering from similar nightmares. Strange psychic interference seems to be POPPING UP all over the place, and not long after that, the brains of the other campers start disappearing, leaving the campers as soulless, TV-obsessed husks. As the hero of the story, Raz is on a mission to solve these various mysteries and uncover the crazy conspiracy behind it all.

The basic plot itself reads like typical platformer fodder, but there's a lot more to Psychonauts' story than can be summed up in a single paragraph. This is largely due to the game's bizarre cast of characters, of which there are many. Raz himself is a highly likable hero; he's cute, heroic, funny, and also a little awkward at times. He fits the bill of the overenthusiastic yet not-quite-ready hero to the letter and it's hard not to feel sympathetic to his plight. But beyond Raz, there's a great supporting cast, with roughly two dozen other characters who play parts both large and small in the story. The counselors consist of Coach Oleander, an overly aggressive drill sergeant; Milla Vodello, a somewhat ditzy and party-happy go-go girl; Agent Nein, a pale-skinned, sweater-sporting scientist of indeterminate Eastern European origin; and Ford Cruller, a mysterious old man who seems to exist in about eight different places at once. These counselors join the crazy array of campers, as well as other strange people and creatures you'll encounter, to drive the storyline, and thanks to the game's excellent design, you'll have no shortage of opportunities to get ATTACHED to them.

Initially, Psychonauts feels like a very open-ended game, especially because upon your first venture into the camp area, you'll find yourself able to just wander around, chatting it up with other campers or even just listening in on their completely INSANE conversations. The camp and its many areas make up a hub world, where you can access lots of different things, including a camp store, where you can buy helpful items, an underground tram that cuts down on backtracking, and all sorts of little hidden areas that yield bonus items. However, the biggest boon for the camp world is all the little bouts of dialogue you can discover. Depending on what stage of the game you're at, the conversations change up quite a bit, meaning you're not often going to hear a lot of repeats. This is great, especially because there's just so much of the dialogue. In some instances, you can literally just stand next to a pair of characters while they converse for about five minutes or longer and never hear the same line twice. And it's almost always really funny stuff.

However, the most interesting aspects of Psychonauts' characters don't come from their real-world conversations, but rather from their internal monologue. As Psychonauts revolves around a bunch of psychics, the bulk of your time will be spent traversing the perils of people's minds. This is where Psychonauts truly shines. You'll be able to enter the minds of more than a dozen different characters in the game, and each mind serves as one of its main levels. Each level is completely unique. For instance, when you enter the head of Coach Oleander, you'll find a war-torn landscape filled with constant explosions, plants made out of ammunition, and, for reasons not immediately apparent, lots and lots of meat. In another example, you enter the mind of a crazed security guard named Boyd Cooper, who is utterly obsessed with nonsensical conspiracies and someone called The Milkman." His mental landscape looks like a 1950s-era suburban neighborhood that's been picked up by a pair of hands

reviewText:
The good -
- A funny, original story with good voice acting and genuinely funny dialogue throughout. Can be childish at times, but it fits with the humor and juxtaposes well with some of the darker and more mature elements.
- Great art direction, despite its age the graphics still don't look dated and fit with the look and feel of the game perfectly. The character design tends more towards cartoony characters whose appearance give you a good outline of their personality, and the environments vary widely from traditional platformer areas to mind bending levels that twist and turn through every axis.
- Tight platformer mechanics, moving around and exploring the environments is easy and encouraged thanks to loads of hidden collectables. Its easy to keep track of your progress, and constantly unlocking something new, or being just about to, will keep you playing that one more level.

The bad -
- Occasional problems with the camera, the usual having to wrestle it under control from a preset position. Part and parcel of 3D platformers ported from consoles.
- Some of the latter levels have some downright unfair sections with long runs between checkpoints and unforgiving level design that can become quite frustrating.
- Optimization problems with Windows 7. There are loads of threads all over the net complaining of crashes and freeze-ups, which seem to only occur on Windows 7. True, running the game in compatibility mode (I used Windows 95) solves this issue but it seems like a glaring problem for a game on Steam, no matter how old.

Personal Highlights (contains level spoilers, no storyline spoilers) -
- Lungfishopolis - Destroying a city populated by fish as a giant Kaiju Theatre version of yourself. Complete with gameplay being interrupted by news flashes as the fish report on your rampage of destruction.
- The Milkman Conspiracy - One of the most head bending levels I've seen in a platformer in recent times.
- Razputin (the main character) is voiced brilliantly by Richard Horvitz (the voice of Invader Zim). YMMV on this one, but as a fan of the show I loved hearing the distinctive voice throughout.

Summary -
Won't be everyone's cup of tea, but if you like platformers and adventure games, Psychonauts is an excellent example of an original and unique take on the genre. It's fun to play, memorable in both its level design and its story, and, frankly, there's not much out there (especially recently) that compares to it. Let down by minor problems that plague many console to PC ports, but they don't hamper it enough to be a standout game.

9/10

Context - 9
Challenge - 8
Catharsis - 8

reviewText: A game with a incredibly unique concept on the platforming genre, Psychonauts is probably one of my new favorite platformers ever. You take the place of Rasputin (which I hoped was going to be the russian leader, but whatever) who has a mysterious past that I will not spoil, as you learn about it as you go on. You end up into a camp for psychics
date:
and unlike the other psychics, these guys are the real deal. You battle enemies by not just fighting them up front, but by going into their mind and fighting their demons. I can't wait to play more, as even the tutorial level is genius, with a general with a mind full of a whole boot camp.

I never did play this game when it was released, but these graphics are still hold up very well, and the voice acting is amazing, especially the general of the camp. The only voice that was a little annoying was Rasputin's, but that might just be a personal preference.

The gameplay is fun, and made me wanted to explore around the world the most I could to collect arrowheads, almost like a Banjo Kazooie game. In fact, the entire game reminds me of a remix on Banjo Kazooie, which, now that I think about it, is genius.

All in all: with the sale for it being only 2 dollars, it is an absolute buy.

reviewText:
I recommend this game tentatively.

Pros:
- Beautiful and Unique Art Style. It reminds me a bit of Invader Zim, but not so much so that I'd declare it a plain rip off.
- Intricate and Masterful storytelling. The plot is interesting and keeps me coming back for more. I'm never just slogging through something hoping for a payoff. It's all a genuinely fun story.
- Likable characters. Even the characters who barely get screen time or have no lines seem to be overflowing with personality. They feel very real, despite being so stylized.
- Fun game mechanics. The psychic abilities are endlessly fun. Levitation is my absolute favorite, mainly because it frees up the movement of your character a lot, but there are several other abilities I really love. On top of being fun, they're necessary. Once a mechanic is introduced, they always give you a reason to use it. While you may eventually stop using it as often, it'll always come back a few more times.
- Dialogue is witty and hilarious. It's not forced comedy like I see a lot of comedy games try to do. It's just funny, in a really natural way, and I found myself actually laughing out loud. Even jokes that fall flat were meant to do so, because the fact that the joke wasn't funny is part of the joke itself.
- The vaults are probably my favorite part of the game. They're a sort of slide show deal, and there are usually two in every level. They're in depth explanations of certain points of that character's life, and they're a joy every time.
- Bosses are challenging, but not impossible. They're all unique and just so fun.

Cons:
- The technology is from the PS2 era, and it shows. Some of the graphics are painfully outdated, and the pitful camera movement is a relic. You have to control the camera movement separately with your mouse, and it can tend to get frustrating during intense fights, trying to control the camera, move your character and target enemies.
- Strange difficulty curve. The entire first section of the game is tutorials (understandably, considering the huge assortment of psychic abilities and mechanics they're trying to introduce) and at some point in the second half it suddenly jumps up to being extremely hard. I had to resort to a few lets plays at some parts because it was just so obtuse what you were supposed to be doing.
- Figments and arrowheads were ridiculously annoying. Figments are somewhat transparent, so they tend to blend into the highly stylized backgrounds, making it almost impossible to know where they are at times. As for the arrowheads, they're practically everywhere, but at times the game demands you actively dig them up which just wasn't fun at all.
- CRASHING. Good god, the crashing. At time of writing, the game has crashed at least 4 or 5 times today, which is why I'm writing this review now, hoping if I let it throw it's little tantrum for about half an hour it'll decide to work so I can continue playing. Perhaps it's just the computer I'm running it on (It's not really a gaming PC, but it is a high powered Mac) but it takes something away from the game when I'm saving every two steps in case the game decides to suddenly freeze and crash.


Overall, I recommend it to anyone who wants to try something entirely new and different. It's a purely fun experience with a few technical issues that tend to drag it down at points. Despite the crashing and a few nit picky issues, I will continue playing it because I'm so invested, but if you don't think you could handle that, or don't have the patience for such a thing, I'd only recommend buying it on sale.

reviewText: Psychonauts is one of those games that you overlook because of it's age. I heard nothing but good things about it but I still was not convinced. One day I decided, why not? and I never looked back... ok I looked back like 30 hours later and a few times inbetween asking myself what I'm doing with my life but that's not relevant to this review.\nSo first off, this is a 3d action-adventure platformer with a light, fun and whacky art direction, everything about this game gives of a facade of humorus dialogue and ridiculous characters, but the underlying tale has a much darker theme going, telling the sad story of dissapointment and faliure, manifesting in insane and unstable human-beings given the shortest straw in life, this is a story about untangeling and getting to the core issue of one's mind and finding ways to overcome those issues.\nThis game shows empathy and heart, it's funny, selfaware and it feels like every nook and crany in this game holds some sort of meaning, it's packed with collectibles and there is always something to do, I pretty much binged this game untill I had collected everything, not something I normally find compelling but this game somehow manages to keep my monkey-mind on track and for that it's easily one of the best games I've played so far, can't wait for the second Psychonauts.

reviewText:
Psychonauts is more than just nostalgia, it's an adventure! It brings me back to games being $30 a pop, and aimed towards style rather than realism. This is a perfect example of a memorable old game. Like many, it's been forgotten over time. I never even played it till i saw it on steam! (mostly because I could never find a copy) But seriously:

The art is fantastic, I really love the detail put into the character models and the different stylizations of each level. The voice acting is pretty great, I especially love Raz and Lili's. The story's fantastic! It has it's comedy elements, over all a nice little story, but if you search deep enough you can find a few deep dark secrets... The gameplay is solid, I rarely had issues.

The only problem I can say with the game is that sometimes Figments are hard to spot. Figments aren't required to complete the game, but they're more so a treasure hunt item so it doesn't matter unless you want to 100% the game. Either way I think you'll enjoy it even if you have to go figment hunting!

reviewText: Double Fine make some really good games, this being one of the best in my opinion, the trailer for this game really doesn’t do it justice and I’ve noticed that in a few double fine games to be honest. They don't usually show off the game for what it really is, nor show its true potential. Just from the trailer, I didn't think this was something I would ever play, but I got it in a bundle and it’s actually an amazing game.\nLike any good game, some parts can be frustrating, but it’s all part of the fun. Because it wasn’t the kind of frustration for me that made me want to give up, more so the kind you want to keep trying again, and then when you do succeed, you feel like you've accomplished something. The story is quite quirky and fun, the dialog can be really humorous at times as well, at least to me. You can definitely tell the creative team of double fine are behind it, there is fun characters to interact with and fun little stories to unfold behind each one. Also, there is a lot of collectables and little Easter eggs to find in the game. It’s not one of those games that it seems like a chore to do, for me it was actually fun. But then again, I do like my collectables in games.\nAll in all, I think it’s an amazing game, it’s definitely worth buying, if I didn't get it in a bundle, I would very happily of spent the money on it knowing now how good it is. I even liked it so much as to go back after my first play through and complete it 100%, achievements and all. Which took around 2 and a half playthroughs, it was a lot of fun. Even though I’ve finished it, I can still see myself going back and playing it again in the future. It’s a very enjoyable game, and I’m glad that I did end up playing it, despite what the trailer made me originally think.

reviewText:
This sure is a great game, one of the lastest masterpieces coming from Tim Schafer.

It's really sad it's really underrated in some points or in general.

Why is this so great, you say? (or not, i'm going to say it anyways), it's totally fun, and really really creative, its fun to play and to progress, funny dialogues, bizarre moments and characters, sometimes you'll get some sad backstory coming from every character.

Also, to keep in mind this: It's not a kids game. Neither +5, neither +10 or +13, despite the art, it has a lot of humour and dialogues that can be only taken serious or get a pun from the game if you're Teen/Adult, sure, a kid can play the game, but only to play, and follow some cliché things from every story of this kind.

Now like every game, there is no perfection whatsoever.

By this i mean, there are some bugs or mechanisms that are quite annoying in some point in the gameplay, sometimes you'll fall down, sometimes you won't grab a ledge, usually you'll touch A LOT of invisible walls, and there are some puzzles that are quite overthinked, or the only way to get the puzzle right it's going with the trial-n-error method, WHICH can take a lot of time and it will turn to be a bit boring, but once you get that right you'll feel really good.

Characters are sure as hell NOT forgettable, they are distinguishable and special, really creative ways to play and make a nice but simple plot.

In terms of port, you'll suffer some FPS drops in the mean time but they are really random, unless, of course, you use a FPS-locker program, because it lacks of FPS lock, so you will probably get 40 fps and then 80 fps but then 20 fps.

Also, one more thing, it also lacks of controller support, but thanks to the internet, you'll get that done boy, with this guide


http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?l=spanish&id=256290412

Thanks for the respective owners of every link, program and guide.

Anyways, if you got here looking for a new game, i can guarnatee that you'll like this game, it has replayability, really.

See ya! and good luck out there

reviewText: Such an imaginative concept that's explored so well. A lot of variety in the gameplay, with radically different scenarios and many powers and types of movements you can use. Hilarious dialogue, charming characters, so much attention to detail (every NPC has dozens and sometimes hundreds of responses and the artistry of some of the locations is astonishing), and lots of collectibles which you are well rewarded for. Clearly made with a lot of love, and you'll fall in love with it too.\nRuns well even on an old PC. There are a few moments where the platforming can get tricky, but the whole game can be done even on a keyboard. Even if you don't care for platformers, make an exception for this one, because this game gives you so much.

reviewText: It has action, humor, and an enthralling story. It's an adventure game like no other featuring children soldiers. It's none other than Psychonauts. You play as Razputin, or Raz for short, who has a dream to become a Psychonaut, a psychic soldier who protects to the world,  before his parents can pick him up from Psychonaut training camp. As he ventures through the camp grounds completing task for his councilors, he stumbles upon something that could mean the end of the world. Through many obstacles and enemies, you must find a way to stop this calamity from happening all before you are picked up from camp. A game of this stature deserves much more praise than what it has received. Tim Schafer did an excellent job on creating a spell bounding game that captures your interest within seconds. A cult-classic in gaming that needs to be played.

reviewText:
One of the most unique and hilarious platformers I have ever played, Psychonauts carries on the Double Fine legacy with near perfect form. The story of Raz and his adventure in a camp for psychics is both charming and at times extremely disturbing, but from beginning to end you can really tell just how much the writers poured their hearts into each and every line.

The gameplay isn't as original, falling in line with most other platformers in terms of mechanics, though the controls do leave a bit to be desired. The levels on the other hand are some of the most bizarre and interesting I've seen in any game, a few harkening back to Double Fine's adventure game roots with some clever puzzles to mix things up.

Everything is brought together with a fantastic art direction. If Tim Burton and Pixar had a lovechild, it would look like Psychonauts. The music is memorable, the voice acting top notch, and overall it is simply a marvelous game that I can recommend to any fan of Double Fine or just 3D platformers in general!

reviewText: Remember that crazy dream you had?  So does this game, and now you get to travel into it.  Has a number of fun psychic powers and an entertaining and wacky storyline.  The platforming is solid and the visuals are wacky without becoming too strange.  A great way to spend some time.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of all-time, and definitely my favorite Double Fine game. Psychonauts is a bundle of joy and love.

There is nothing I dislike about this game, at all. I used to play a lot of funny platforming game years and years ago, but don't as much now. I loved playing things like Crash Bandicoot or, going back further generations, to things like Earthworm Jim. When it comes to weird humor though, Psychonauts is probably the top.

The story of Psychonauts starts out simple but gets significantly more involved as it goes along, getting decently complex as things actually become a mystery. But the way of solving the puzzles is the best. Delving into the minds of different characters along the way, using their thoughts as levels, is awesome. Each stage in the game is so unique and interesting that I will replay them all forever. All of the characters are so interesting and have their own ticks, and the graphics and sounds (including voice acting) are so well-done. Nothing is wrong at all with the design.

Raz, your character, gets interesting power-ups along the way, making exploration fun and opening up random puzzles. Finding the easter eggs in the levels is fun, from the basic collectibles (enabling you to buy upgrades) to especially the memories. The most stand-out ones for me are in Milla's mind, but just about all of them are rewarding in some way.

The platforming itself is clean and not too frustrating, though some levels take a bit of adjusting to, such as the angles in the Milkman stage. And exploring outside of the levels is just as fun because Double Fine developed the world with lots of detail. Wandering around and finding some little incidental cutscene is great, especially since nearly everything in the game is really funny and off-the-wall.

If you don't find the game's sense of humor enjoyable, then that's a shame. But I have to say that this game is one of the most enjoyable experiences I have ever had. Go play it, now!

reviewText:
TL;DR: A great story with good gameplay. I recommend you play it, but SPECIFICALLY on Windows, with an Xbox 360 Controller, and with the Psychopad mod.

Psychonauts was the first game that I ever bought (with money) on my Steam account. After hearing good reviews (such as the one from Yahtzee on Zero Punctuation), I had decided to pick it up. In the end, I'd consider it one of my favorite games of all time.

The core gameplay actually feels a lot like a 3D Mario game. It's a 3rd Person 3D Platformer with some fairly intricate platforming. This difficulty is a little on the tough side, but it never really feels vicious other than the last level of the game. The game gives you a double jump from the beginning of the game, which makes the platforming a bit easier, and about a third of the way through the game, it gives you an ability that allows you to fall slower, which makes some of the later-game platforming more bearable. Your main attack is a punch that has a fairly large range. You also gain abilities as you progress though the game that allow you to attack from more of a distance. For these abilities, the game gives you a lock-on system that is very similar to Zelda's Z-Targeting. This usually works well, but can get frustrating at times when there are a lot of enemies on the screen at once.

The level design in this game is excellent. The story behind the levels is that you are entering the minds of different characters, so each level is designed to represent that character's psyche. Because all of the characters you enter the minds of are well characterized, each level is itself a strong representation of the characters. The most interesting levels are correlated to the most interesting characters, with Boyd's level being particularly famous. There are hidden memory vaults, along with scripted events and cutscenes in the levels that help to further characterize the people who's minds you enter, helping to create a better overall connection between the levels you play in and the story that moves the game along.

The story in the game is fantastic. You play a psychic boy named Raz who runs away from home (which happens to be a circus), to sneak into a summer camp that trains psychic kids to try to make them psychic secret agents" called psychonauts. He discovers a conspiracy that threatens the entire camp
date: and it's up to Raz to save the camp. All the characters that you meet in the game are all well characterized
recommended: and makes the story much more interesting. The game has a lot of humor in it
hoursPlayed: and Double Fine has done a good job of making sure the jokes actually work. Psychonauts is one of the funniest games I've ever played.\n\nOne aspect of the game that I didn't really like was the leveling system. reviewText:
Positive
+ Expertly crafted story and writing in general; with entertaining and unique characters, as well as intelligent dialogue/humour that very few games can match
+ Some very bizarre imagery, with an interesting art style
+ Wide variety of gameplay styles: with the various PSI abilities, and some of the best 3D platforming in the industry; the level design especially is both imaginative and memorable
+ Clocking in at around 10 hours of playtime (many more if you wish to collect all of the various collectibles), the game is lengthy and doesn’t drag on for too long nor feel too short.


Negative
- Occasionally the camera can be a little awkward, especially when it comes to the platforming, making missed jumps a little irritating, as well as the targeting system being a little iffy at times
- Somewhat inconsistent difficulty curve: though for the most part the game is relatively easy, some parts may take a few more tries to beat than expected.


Verdict
“Put simply, one of the most memorable and fun games I’ve ever played. Unfortunately, the game sold fairly poor on release, so a sequel to this game ever being created is unlikely, which makes the ending even more bittersweet. But don’t let that put you off from playing this witty masterpiece of a game. You will not regret it.”

9/10 TJBs

reviewText:
Creative? Original? Funny? Yes, yes, and yes.

Psychonauts has joined that list of hipster games. You know the ones: games that everyone missed when they were first released, but we go back to them now because of good word of mouth and constant top 10" anointment in gaming magazines. Having played Psychonauts apparently makes a person something of a gaming historian. So... I had to try it!

While Psychonauts is a true original

reviewText:
It's a tragedy that there are not more games like this.

Psychonauts is a 3rd-person 3D platformer which puts you in the shoes of Raz, a psychic prodigy who ran away from his circus family to join a summer camp for Psychics, in training to become Psychonauts.

Psychonauts has you enter the minds of all sorts of different people and experience their inner psyche up close and personal. As you can imagine, this leads to some interesting visual design choices and a lot of laughs to boot.

The gameplay is solid, Raz handles pretty well. One downside is that you can only have 3 abilities mapped to buttons at any one time and so you will be switching these constantly depending on the situation. Most of the game has you running around in peoples heads, collecting items and avoiding hazards.

The graphics look dated, as they should do. It was an old game and a console port as well. It still holds up well, though, thanks to the great art direction, fluid animations and colorful environments. The audio is also fantastic, it has a great soundtrack and some excellent voice talent.

This is a must-have if you're a PC gamer.

reviewText:
Exploring the minds of other campers was so entertaining that I feel it made this game worth it in spite of the near constant crashing issues that seem to plague a segment of the playerbase and the other negatives I'll get to.

Pros:
-Each level feels distitinct from the others and no one level is that level" that I hated to play
-Story pacing is adequate
date: I felt introduced to new plot points often enough to remain interested\n-The characters are fleshed out enough that the player can dig into their pasts and motivations through dialog or power  interactions (claravoiyance lets you see how they view you
recommended:
for example)
-The story was coherent and had a satsifiying conclusion and the main characters exhibited growth as characters

Cons:
-The player is rewarded with additional powers or upgrades by collecting a large number of collectables but the upgrades feel largely useless and the entire game could be beaten easily while ignoring the collectables
-The Confusion grenade power was shoehorned in for one mini-boss and one boss fight in the same level and then has no effect on any enemies following that point.
-There is a story-related point where the player recieves the Levitation power but subsequent levels are not designed around its use and it utterly removes all platforming from the game.
-Constant crashing. This is only alleviated by the game autosaving at every loading screen so the player loses no progress.
-The arrowhead currency is mostly useless except the two times the player is forced to hunt for them to buy an item in order to progress with the game. One of these two items is a dousing rod that only helps find more arrowheads to save up for the more expensive plot-related item.

Again

reviewText: I quite enjoy this game, as I was not able to play when it came out (just didn't have the money as I was too young to really make any amount of money at the time) but it's nice to have it ported over to Steam. A couple of problems, the mapping for keyboard only is........ Well it leaves something to be desired, it's not game breaking and if you really tried I'm sure it would all make sense, but the worst part of that is if you want to use a controller. Yes yes, I know, no true PC gamer would stray from the mouse and keyboard, but this game was never designed for mouse and keyboard, so I thought obviously using one would be preferred, but it's really not. It auto maps, but some things still require the keyboard and mouse along with it. I found a couple of glitches early on, stuttering frames where some audio cut in and out (nothing terrible, just noticable) and areas where the frames just drop for no apparent reason. But, all in all for a port, this is well worth the money, and coming from someone who can't have his nastalgia goggles on, I'd recommend it for sure.

reviewText: The writing is very funny, which you won’t see in this industry very often, because in this apparently, in this industry stupid drama is better than smart comedy. The story is very original and interesting, I don’t wish to spoil it so you will have to trust me on this one. Every character has his own personality and struggles, even the unimportant ones, which is nice to see in this land of Mr. Johnny Testosterone Space Marine and Mrs. Sassy Action Chick.\nThe gameplay is intresting, but it has it’s flaws (they might be forgivable), the psychic powers are awesome and the boss fights really require skill, every boss has it’s own weak spot, you have to deduce it by watching it’s attacks. On the other hand the camera can be a little female dog some times. The combat outside the boss fights is kind of meh. The difficulty curve is a little bit messed up, there were sequences near the end that almost made break my keyboard. However I never stopped playing it, because I really wanted to see the ending, and I haven’t left disappointed.\nThe ending promised a sequel and I really hope to see the day when Psychonauts 2 will be released!

reviewText:
Seriously people, it's a cult classic for a reason. If you're planning on buying this wait until it's on crazy sale (Bought my copy when it was going for practically 1.75$ CAN ) because around the halfway point when there's not much left to learn the game gets MAD difficult, and if you buy it for the 9.99$ current full price, you might feel like you have wasted your money.

Besides that, who honestly doesn't want to fool (Without spoiling anything) agents into thinking you're one of them? Or become Godzilla? Of hell, simply light things on fire? This game really has it all in lue of imagenation (Here's looking at you Godzilla level that took me forever). Plus you get to play as a kid from the circus that decided to run away from it (Rather than TO it as many children must have planned to do at some point in childhood before they were allowed to cross the streets by themselves... I know I did... Sat on the curb for three hours huffing that my plans had been foiled by the road, what can I say, I was -and still am- adventerous)

All in all, it's a darn good game. You'd be hard pressed to find another Tim Schafer gem like this one...

Critisizm would be that darn difficulty curve... Oh and like, four of the kids in the game are aggrivatingly annoying as ♥♥♥♥, but at least there's only one 'Escort' thing that's totally optional, but nets you some sweet, sweet arrowheads (Money in this game) if you do it (And it's simple as hell if you're quick to reassure the character that they can make it). Other than that, it's a really good game.

reviewText: Haven't played much of it yet, I'm still at the campsite, but the gameplay is really fun. It's a 3D platformer with fun dialogue and fun combat, it has several collectibles in each level, including 'figments' which are 2D outlines of various things. There are lots of these to collect and it keeps exploration high. You start with pretty basic attacks - a punch combo and a ground pound - but every 10 levels you gain more. If you like 3D platformers, give it a shot. I could compare this to Ty the tasmanian tiger, which had partially similar visuals and controls, they also both had more powers or weapons available as you progressed. If you played and enjoyed Ty, You'll enjoy this.

reviewText:
Let me just start off with saying, that i LOVE this game. I have played it through 4 times now and i recently picked it up on steam and 100% completed the game. The story is very interesting and somewhat original. A lot of people say, that the game hasn't aged well, but the cartoony and sometimes dodgy graphics somehow appeal to me more than modern games. I do agree, that the controls are a bit akward without a contoler, but you can get used to them.

The most important aspect about this game to me is that it scratches an itch... The countles collectibles are not obligatory to collect, but the ranking sistem makes them very rewarding. The feeling that you get after collecting every figment in a level is great and you feel like you have achieved something. (figments are one of the collectible and often hard to notice 2D models that make levels look full and colorfull)

Lastly i want to talk about the music. In my oppinion it is very well made and fits in the rather bizzare world of the game very well. I was very happy when i had the chance to get the official sountracks from the Humble Bundle.

This game is a lovely little gem from the 2005 and it's well worth its price. I can't recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
I've never seen people clamor so hard for a sequel as in the case of Psychonauts. The constant hype and praise heaped onto the game can give people unrealistic expectations and keep them away from it, which is a shame. Before I go into trying to convince you to give it a chance, though, I should point out that it is not a perfect game (while keeping spoilers to a minimum).

• As a previous-gen title, the graphics in Psychonauts aren't stellar. They're fine enough to my eyes, but the blurry textures might discourage some.
• The PC version is pretty much unplayable without a controller. More on that at the end of this review.
• There's a notorious difficulty curve, though less so if you've played other 3D platformers. You'll spend a bit getting used to the controls and game mechanics, sail smooth for the majority of the game (sometimes being thrown a hard puzzle or boss fight), then spend the last level with half your bloodstream composed of adrenaline as you're forced to use everything you've learned under stressful circumstances. The achievement for the last level got its name for a reason.

Okay, now I can gush and tell you why you SHOULD play this:

• It's funny! I laugh at the same jokes I did when I played it on Xbox years ago, and then some since I'm old enough to understand more of them.
• Assuming you're using a controller, the gameplay is flawless. Though you might be tempted to blame the game when you fall or tumble, the acrobatics are of the highest quality, which you would hope for in a platformer.
• The story. I won't go into details here, since it's more fun to let you find it all out for yourself. The Steam product description provides a nice teaser, but it's only a small part of the tale.
• The characters. Oh boy, this'll be the big bullet point. You wonder why people beg so much for a sequel? This is why. Whispering Rock is a summer camp filled with kids and (technically) employees, with personalities all their own. When I say that the description is only a small part, this is what I'm talking about. Almost all of the characters grow as people through the course of the game's events, and watching them do so is half the fun. Between levels (hell, before you start the first one), you'll want to wander around the campground for a bit and talk to the kids. Pretty much all of them have their own tiny subplots, even if they're just a handful of dialogue spaced out by an hour or two. A band tries to get off the ground, young love is in the air, and boys become men. They're all as compelling. But talking sometimes isn't enough. Some people have their traumatic secrets locked away, and you'll have to seek them out in the darkest corners of their minds.
• The levels. This is another area where the game shines. Just like the people and their minds in which you'll find these lands, no two are alike. Again, I'd rather let you find this all out for yourself, but if playing through a Godzilla parody and defeating Napoleon Bonaparte at his own game don't sound appealing, this probably isn't for you.

I could probably go on and find more to talk about, but then I'd be contributing to the problem of overhyping the game. It's not for no reason, though. In an industry where the best-selling game are first-person shooters, devoid of atmosphere, denied color, and depicting swaths of people getting killed in massive conflicts, Psychonauts is the antithesis. It's a tribute to childhood adventure presented as a colorful, humorous, varied third-person platformer with no (real) shooting to speak of. When you see 'MODERN BATTLE WAR 2K14: EXTRA GREY EDITION' sell copies by the millions every year, with no sequel in sight for Psychonauts due to underperforming in sales, you might begin to understand why people cling to this game like a liferaft.

Is it flawless? No. I spent the entire second paragraph on that.

Does it have a deep story making a commentary on the human condition? Probably not, but maybe. Certainly not Raz's; the story of a young boy trying to achieve his childhood dream has been told a thousand times over. But some of Whispering Rock's residents are flawed characters that have suffered genuine tragedy, but who may yet overcome their pasts, if only extended a genuine helping hand (I might be overthinking it, but I just love these characters so much).

But the most important thing is that it's fun, which is the basis for a good video game. This is a game full of secrets, collectibles, and challenges. Other games with less have found love, and all the other stuff just made it that much better.

This is where the review stops.

This is my stop sign.

Want to get that awful forced joke? Play the game.

-NOTE ON CONTROLLER-

Psychonauts' biggest problem is exclusive to the PC version. I HIGHLY recommend using a gamepad. Your best choice is the Xbox 360 Controller, given its high degree of support and close resemblance to the Xbox and PS2 controllers, with which Double Fine designed Psychonauts in mind. However, while you can just plug it in and be ready to go, inexperienced players won't know all of the buttons by heart. Steam user v00d00man has addressed this problem by developing an application called PsychoPad, which will replace the button images with the 360 controller's (or generic gamepad numeric buttons if you opted for something else).

http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2151566

You might also check out PsychoWide, which crops the cutscenes to your resolution instead of stretching them.

reviewText: I quite enjoy this game, as I was not able to play when it came out (just didn't have the money as I was too young to really make any amount of money at the time) but it's nice to have it ported over to Steam. A couple of problems, the mapping for keyboard only is........ Well it leaves something to be desired, it's not game breaking and if you really tried I'm sure it would all make sense, but the worst part of that is if you want to use a controller. Yes yes, I know, no true PC gamer would stray from the mouse and keyboard, but this game was never designed for mouse and keyboard, so I thought obviously using one would be preferred, but it's really not. It auto maps, but some things still require the keyboard and mouse along with it. I found a couple of glitches early on, stuttering frames where some audio cut in and out (nothing terrible, just noticable) and areas where the frames just drop for no apparent reason. But, all in all for a port, this is well worth the money, and coming from someone who can't have his nastalgia goggles on, I'd recommend it for sure.

reviewText:
Positive

+ Expertly crafted story and writing in general; with entertaining and unique characters, as well as intelligent dialogue/humour that very few games can match
+ Some very bizarre imagery, with an interesting art style
+ Wide variety of gameplay styles: with the various PSI abilities, and some of the best 3D platforming in the industry; the level design especially is both imaginative and memorable
+ Clocking in at around 10 hours of playtime (many more if you wish to collect all of the various collectibles), the game is lengthy and doesn’t drag on for too long nor feel too short.


Negative

- Occasionally the camera can be a little awkward, especially when it comes to the platforming, making missed jumps a little irritating, as well as the targeting system being a little iffy at times
- Somewhat inconsistent difficulty curve: though for the most part the game is relatively easy, some parts may take a few more tries to beat than expected.


Verdict

“Put simply, one of the most memorable and fun games I’ve ever played. Unfortunately, the game sold fairly poor on release, so a sequel to this game ever being created is unlikely, which makes the ending even more bittersweet. But don’t let that put you off from playing this witty masterpiece of a game. You will not regret it.”

9/10

reviewText:
This game has been hyped up for me for years and i'm only now getting around to play it. I'm delighted to say it does not dissappoint. The writing is top notch , everything from the style, dialogue and humor. The variety of situations and locations is a real treat.

Gameplay is a bit of a mixed bag. Combat is fine... just ok. Platforming ranges from very satisfying to controller snapping frustration and the game has uneven difficult spikes. While the story and pacing is excellent a lot of the quests or objectives boil down to fetch quests.

Overall by no means a perfect game but its varietation from the normal games round up and sheer uniqueness make it stand out.
9/10

reviewText: The writing is very funny, which you won’t see in this industry very often, because in this apparently, in this industry stupid drama is better than smart comedy. The story is very original and interesting, I don’t wish to spoil it so you will have to trust me on this one. Every character has his own personality and struggles, even the unimportant ones, which is nice to see in this land of Mr. Johnny Testosterone Space Marine and Mrs. Sassy Action Chick.\nThe gameplay is intresting, but it has it’s flaws (they might be forgivable), the psychic powers are awesome and the boss fights really require skill, every boss has it’s own weak spot, you have to deduce it by watching it’s attacks. On the other hand the camera can be a little female dog some times. The combat outside the boss fights is kind of meh. The difficulty curve is a little bit messed up, there were sequences near the end that almost made break my keyboard. However I never stopped playing it, because I really wanted to see the ending, and I haven’t left disappointed.\nThe ending promised a sequel and I really hope to see the day when Psychonauts 2 will be released!

reviewText:
Masterpiece.

You need more? This is an adventure/platformer, from the 2000, so it aged a bit. Adventure features, zeldaish kind of thing. And platformer but the 2000 3D, which means N64 period, the first age of it. You can finish it easily if you are a gamer, you may struggle a bit if you are a casual. It is long, weird and gamerish, so if you are into that, got an X360 controller, you will love it. If not...

You need even more? This is Tim Schafer last marvel (after that, I gave up on him, unfortunately). So if you loved previous T.S. works of art like Day of the Tentacle, Full Throttle, or Grim Fandango, and found they too were masterpieces, do not think further and buy Psychonauts.

You need always more?! This is a BRILLIANT work of art. You can enjoy it as a platformer passionate, because it is really rich regarding that. You can enjoy it adventure wise, because there is TONS to collect, reminiscent of N64 times like Banjo&Kazooie style. You can enjoy it storywise because it is huge, meticulously written, an old souvenir from the 90s point and clicks where you had to WRITE a STORY before developing a game.

Great music, great dialogues, very original world, very smart and psychological and analytical scenario... and it is a real Tim Schafer universe, the real one, not today's. DO RECOMMEND that masterpiece.

reviewText:
I have to preface this a bit;  I love this game as much as anyone, but it's tedious if you want it to be.  When I first played this, I basically marathoned it over two long sittings.  I did everything I could, completely 100%'d the game.

Now, returning to it after having bought it again on sale (Originally played on Xbox), I have to admit the game isn't suited to doing in such a complete fashion again.  Everything holds up, for the most part.  I absolutely adore running around the campgrounds, seeking out various items.  It's pretty basic, but the atmosphere invoked being so similar to that of a Saturday morning cartoon just pulls at my heartstrings something fierce.  When you get into the meat of the game, however, it falls apart a bit.  The platforming is mostly simple, and that's no issue.  It does what it should and it does it well enough.  The game is truly unique in its presentation, that's what makes it worth playing.  The real issue is with the figment collecting.  It's tedious as can be.

It's like playing Banjo Kazooie or another collectathon, but everything you want to get, runs away from you.

Through walls.

It's very frustrating to run through a level more than once to find a chicken that just happens to hide in walls until the very second you turn around.

All in all though, wonderful game.  A must play for anyone that loves games in my opinion, just don't get too caught up in seeing every little detail of this game.  The little things just hinder an otherwise amazing game, filled with detail and character not frequently seen.

reviewText:
If you happen to be a Millennial gamer, Psychonauts needs to be on your gaming short-list.  Equal parts Nintendo platformer, LucasArts adventure, and 1990s era Nickelodeon cartoon, it was tailor-made to put a smile on your face.

Whispering Rock Summer Camp is the home of our hero for the duration of the story, and much as Hogwarts instructs young wizards, this retreat is a school for psychics.  Using his mental abilities, Razputin will invade the thoughts of friend and foe alike, and these mindscapes will function as a range of diverse levels.  Ever have somebody tell you that some scary creature was more afraid of you than you were of it?  Raz has one of these moments with a giant mutated lungfish, and upon entering its head, he finds himself filling the role of Godzilla in a city of tiny lungfish.  This type of inventive fun has helped Psychonauts climb onto my own top ten list, and only the most curmudgeonly of cynics would fail to say the same.

For a full review, check out:
http://amanandhismouse.com/psychonauts.html

reviewText:
I just recently finished Psychonauts. Sadly, I did not do it well enough to have gotten all the achievements -- I'm debating a second playthrough to get those I'm missing.

Nevertheless, it's a truly fun game.  Yes, it's a platformer, so you will spend some time just trying to make certain jump sequences, or hunting for a missing thing when you thought you already checked the whole level, or replaying a boss fight because the camera angles are often terrible. But yes, despite that it's funny and fun and it made me laugh out loud quite a bit at the ridiculousness of it all.

You play Raz, a young boy who has run away from the circus to join in at Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp and hopefully to become a Psychonaut -- an international mental agent.  The levels are insane -- your slightly abnormal summer camp (filled with other psychic children) soon becomes an exploration of the other minds around you, in all their whacky weirdness.

Now ... back to debating whether to finish all the achievements...
