reviewText: I had this game when I was very young, when it first came out on the original XBox. I played it for hours on end, day in and day out. Nothing was alble to stop me. Then, one day, I happened to look at the bottom of the disk and noticed that I couldn't see the silvery part very well because it had been scratched so badly. I played it for another day or so and suddenly it wouldn't work anymore. Seeing as they didn't make the game anymore and we couldn't resurface the disk, I was out of luck. Until the day I saw it on Steam. I bought it faster than instantly and, as of today, my 10-year goal to finish the game has been completed.\n\n8/10       Unfortunately, even though it's my favoritest game of all time, there are some bugs and things that aren't smoothed out, such as moving while turning the camera sometimes messes up and some swingy bars are hard to grab onto, but all in all there are some great puzzles and a wonderful story with humor mixed in somewhere along the way. Definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
Bias: I am a dino. I like to dream I have super psychic powers.

Review long time coming. One of the first games I got on steam. If you have not played this game. You should
Quirky, funny, and involves a lot of brain stealing shenanigans. Totally worth playing this. To be honest, I have enjoyed all the Double Fine titles I have played - This one led to me playing Brutal Legend and Costume Quest.

Your quest is to allow the power of your untapped mind to save the kids of Whispering Rock from having their minds stolen and used by the mad man.

This is a fun puzzle platformer with a lot of imagination and creativity. A lot of interesting backgrounds and imagery to suck you into the world of psychic powers. It was an enjoyable experience solving puzzles and fight bosses throughout the game

I do hope a sequel is released. It would definitely go to the top of my to play list.

10/10 from me. Though the game is from 2005, it is still enjoyable and quite playable. With strong story, good puzzles, and fun boss fights.

reviewText:
Gex + Banjo Kazooie + Camp Lazlo + psychic powers.

Do yourself a favor if you ever get around to playing this gem.

Do not go out of the way to collect the little bananas/musical notes/figments. Getting every little item might satisfy your OCD but will detract from the experience overall when you spend upwards of an hour or more on each and every map combing every square inch for that little picture that fades in and out.

When you get to the end of the game it automatically creates a point-of-no return save. You can use that save and from there revisit ever level to get every little item but only IF you feel so inclined. Once you hit the point of no return just fling yourself at that brick wall of a final level and it will crumble against your fists oh so satisfyingly.

Intentinoally annoying characters have never been good. They will continue to never be good.

Physics can be a real ♥♥♥ pain (lol 3D platformers) but this game is practically devoid of any punishment for messing up.

The less you participate in scavenging the more fun you will have.

reviewText: For the first game of Double Fine to be released, I'd say this one was a great starting point. Unique story, creative worlds, amazing characters, and a beautiful musical score can show how great this game truly is. However, slightly stiff controls and a weird camera can ruin the game, and most of the side quests are just incredibly long collect-a-thons. However, if you enjoy a good mind-dive, then this is a game I'd recommend. Just don't drink the milk.

reviewText:
Psychonauts is quite possibly the best platform game I have ever played. In this game, you play as Razputin (or Raz for short), a child acrobat that has ran away from the circus to become a psychonaut, an agent with psionic powers that is able to travel through one’s mind and cure them of their trauma or mental illness. The superpower available are marksmanship (which is Raz’s range attack) telekinesis, pyrokinesis, shield, invisibility, levitation, clairvoyance (which allows Raz to see through the eyes of the NPCs), and confusion.

All of these psionic powers are not just something Raz can do: they ALL have a purpose in the game. The use of certain psionic powers is required to progress further into the game. As I played this game, repetition was at a minimum as the objectives for each level are NEVER reused. Each of the game’s bosses have different strategies in order to defeat them, so you’ll never feel like you’re fighting the same boss twice.

Razputin actually happens to be voiced by Richard Steven Horvitz, the same voice actor the provided the voice of Invader Zim. Psychonauts was designed by Tim Schafer, who also designed the critical successes yet commercial failures Grim Fandango and Brütal Legend. Just like these two games, Psychonauts was a critical success, but a commercial failure. Out of all the platform video games I’ve played, Psychonauts definitely has the most innovation, which is one of my two favorite words when it comes to video games (the other being “variety”).

While I absolutely adore this game, there were only two problems I had with it: one was that the common enemy known as the censor was pretty overused in much of the game. There is also a character called Sheegor who has just the most annoying voice (fortunately, Sheegor doesn’t appear in most of the game)! Another problem I had with this game is it kept crashing (possible due to it being an older game). However, I was able to find a solution and you can find it by clicking  here.

For the great game that Psychonauts is, I would love see a sequel. Markus Persson (the creator of Minecraft) had even offered to fund the sequel, but later changed his mind. Unlike most platform games, Psychonauts is not designed specifically for kids as it was rated T by the ESRB for crude humor and language. The game has usually minor swear words and some of the game’s jokes did make me laugh a little. If you have not checked out this game, I strongly suggest that you do so. If there was a sequel, I would certainly pay full retail price for it.

reviewText: Psychonauts is easily one of the best platformers I have ever played. It's really creative and immersive, and just the mere concept is genius. reviewText: I'd heard so much about this game before I finally received it as a gift this Christmas and, after only an hour playing it, it's holding up to my expectations well.  The characters and their world are imaginative, the style of the art and environments are appealing to all varieties, and the game perpetuates a healthy sense of humour that's more and more rare as time goes on.  Give this a try; it'll take you back to the golden age.  I'm sure that as I continue to play, I'll only have more praises to spill here.

reviewText: This easily deserves the title of Cult Classic. Its a wonderful platformer that hits all the right points of a classic 3D platformer. The humor is wonderful but not to far over edge. They make almost every character memorable, from Raz to Linda to Mikhail. There are some glitches and otherthings but they are easy over look. The game really rewards players for thinking outside the box when it comes to movement and general puzzle solving. reviewText: I bought Psychonauts after I was amazed by storyline and everything of Brutal Legend, another game by Double Fine. And even though I wasn't so enthusiastic at the beginning, I can tell that it's probably the second best game I played this year (well, I mostly play older games, nevermind), after aforementioned Brutal Legend. The story is just fantastic, there are tons of collectibles (which I really like in every game) and intelligent humor. Even graphics is quite good as for game released in 2005, but it's the least important thing. Oh, and I forgot to mention the voices are just epic (Sheegor voice is masterpiece). Game is almost perfect, but well, the controls are definetely not perfect. I used mouse and keyboard, but still it was sometimes hard to move between menus. I also had some problems with camera, especially in narrower places, like small rooms or caves. Everything else is perfect. Except the fact that after 8 years there's still no Psychonauts 2. I still hope that cash I spent on this game will one day make my dream of Psychonauts 2 come true.\n\nOh, almost forgot: MR. POKEYLOPE IS MY KING, LALALA EVERYTHING
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Psychonauts seems like a rather polarizing game in that some people seem to think it's pure gold and some people think it's awful. Which group you'll fall into depends on weather you're the kind person who can allow things like excellent story-telling and charming arti direction excuse a few minor gameplay issues, or if you're the kind of twitching, Ritalin popping, XBox owner who falls into a coma when they go without killing something for five seconds. I'm just going to list out of context some of the things that occur in Psychonauts: a telekinetic bear, a dentist who harvests brains instead of teeth, and a sequence wherein you become a giant  monster and terrorize a society of fish. A game that features all of these things simply cannot be criticized. It's against the law or something. Now so your next course of action should probably be to buy it if you haven't already.

reviewText: Yep, Psychonauts is good. The levels are varied and interesting. The writing is funny. There's a lot of fun, different mechanics/abilities to use. It's an action-adventure with lots of platforming. Judging jumps can be a little tricky in 3D. This made part of the end of the game really more frustrating than it should have been, but that didn't mar the experience much. 20 minutes of 20 hours sucked. There is a bit of puzzle solving in the game. The graphics of course look a bit dated now, but the art style still really helps the look of the game hold up over time and it was often pretty to look at. Overall, Psychonauts is a really well put together game. I was impressed.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Psychonauts is a classic. While often described as a platformer it really is just another way for Tim Schaeffer to tell a story as he always has, this time through a hub world action platformer rather than a point-and-click adventure. As confident and compelling protagonist Raz you explore the minds of others to learn more about yourself all the while building and adding new psychic powers to your repertoire. If you like action and adventure with some platforming thrown in Psychonauts will gladly scratch that itch and have you coming back for more. With full controller support and achievements this is a must own for any Steam gamer.

reviewText: I use to own this game on the PS2 but I do not have it anymore. It is really engaging in terms of the story, graphics, and crude humor. The NPCs have a interesting background story that you can understand in a 1 minute long slide.  Tim Schafer definitely gave the world something memorable but it's just a shame that it did not do well in sales because of lack of promotions. I only found out about this game because I was shopping at the USED section of the game store. reviewText:
I absolutely love this game to pieces! I would recommend it to everyone! Especially to people who have a sense of humor (or dark humor, whichever one you perfer). Even though it plays better on the original Xbox, I don't think anyone should miss playing this game at all on the PC... I would also recommend a USB controller to play; it's well worth it.

As for the story, it revolves around a young psychic named Raz, who ran away from his home to pursue his dream of becoming a Psychonaut, who are an organization of psychics who help out in various other things around the world. He ends up at Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp, where they train people to become Psychonauts, and is also a summer camp for psychic children. But, all is not right at the camp, and it is up to Raz to stop a dastardly plan that will threaten the world!

... Anyway, that's my little summary of the story without spoiling too much. :B

So, in other words... Get this game. Now! :U

reviewText:
So good.  I just finished playing this for the second time, and I'm actually kinda sad now that I don't have more Psychonauts to play when I come home from work.

The most stand-out thing about this game is just that it makes me smile. Like a real, physical grin, not just an internal chuckle.

Unfortunately the conventional wisdom about the platforming is still kinda true too. It's not universally terrible, but it fights you just a little too much in key spots. But in the end, it's all good. Deus Ex has goofy voice acting, Thief has bad animations, Psychonauts has glitchy platforming. (Although probably above-average for 3D platformers.) It's still an all-time classic.

Looks pretty great on the PC too, and the PC version works well with my 360 pad. One note: if you're playing with a 360 pad and notice any issues with the button icons, you could try applying this fix: http://www.doublefine.com/forums/viewthread/4952/

reviewText: Psychonauts is my favorite game (so far :P). It is an action platformer about a ten year old psychic named Razpution AKA Raz. This game is mainly story based with puzzle solving, a simple fighting system, and platforming. This game has a few bugs, bad camera angles (occasionaly), and not so great graphics, but this was a PS2 and X-Box game so it didn't bother me to much. This game offered serveral different psychic abilities and unique boss fights. Psychonauts contained my favorite video game levels of all time, the milkman conspiricy. I was also still able to play and enjoy this game with a PC that does not run the best with games. Overall I give this game 9/10.

reviewText:
So this was a game that's been present in my life some way or another for quite some time, to the point where I had 3 copies of it, but only in this year, 2013, did I sit down and dedicate the time to play it. It was better than I could have possibly imagined. Sure, I played the most updated version on the Mac, so it was cleaner looking and probably controlled smoother, but it felt so good for a game that by all rights should have aged a lot more. And the ideas! Oh my. It's unprecedented for a platformer to have convincing reasons for why you can't swim or the MC's uncanny ability to swing from ledge to ledge so elegantly.

I felt it struggled along and got pretty frustrating throughout the overlong tutorial section of the game if you don't know what you're doing, but nothing has payed off so much so fast. From the time I entered Lungfishopolis and all the way through the Asylum levels, I just never wanted to stop playing.

And I never wanted it to end.

reviewText:
Grandma went to the K-Mart and bought me this game the other day, it is about one of Grandpa's old friends from the war. In it, Grandpa's friend, Arthur spends his days in an underground cave and also does janitor work. It features one of Grandpa's favorite things ever in a video game. Milk. In a mission you drink milk and stop spys from stealing all of the milk. Grandma sure loves Grandpa's milk... ;)

I let Billy play this game and he never came out of his room, I had to tell him his girlfriend was in the hospital to get him to leave, because nothing else worked. I was kidding of course, but he cried for weeks thinking she had cancer.

Grandpa gives this game a 10/10 because it has Grandpa's friend in it, milk, and Billy likes it.

reviewText: I bought Psychonauts after I was amazed by storyline and everything of Brutal Legend, another game by Double Fine. And even though I wasn't so enthusiastic at the beginning, I can tell that it's probably the second best game I played this year (well, I mostly play older games, nevermind), after aforementioned Brutal Legend. The story is just fantastic, there are tons of collectibles (which I really like in every game) and intelligent humor. Even graphics is quite good as for game released in 2005, but it's the least important thing. Oh, and I forgot to mention the voices are just epic (Sheegor voice is masterpiece). Game is almost perfect, but well, the controls are definetely not perfect. I used mouse and keyboard, but still it was sometimes hard to move between menus. I also had some problems with camera, especially in narrower places, like small rooms or caves. Everything else is perfect. Except the fact that after 8 years there's still no Psychonauts 2. I still hope that cash I spent on this game will one day make my dream of Psychonauts 2 come true.\n\nOh, almost forgot: MR. POKEYLOPE IS MY KING, LALALA EVERYTHING

reviewText: Psychonauts is a PS2-era action platformer. Developed by Double Fine and originally published by Majesco, it was released in 2005 for the Xbox, and 2006 for the PC and Playstation 2.It was reviewed well, but sold poorly, and has garnered a cult following. It's not an old game, but a lot has changed since it came out. Let's see how it holds up today.\n\nIt stars the young wanna-be Psychonaut" Razputin

votesFunny: they want to send Raz home

column18: but it is charming and well written. The creativity behind the game is exceptional. Levels all take place in people's heads. Literally. Raz gets sucked into their brain through a tiny door. It's basically Extreme Makeover: Therapy Edition. You help people with their mental health
column19: in the most fun way possible. No two levels are the same
column20: just like people's minds. And just like the levels

column27: and interesting.\n\nThere's not much more to be said about Psychonauts without giving spoilers. This is truly one of those games that you are better off jumping in head first with reckless abandon. Don't look anything up about this game. You'll thank me later."

reviewText: The most creative game I have ever played.  I absolutely loved this game for many different reasons but I think my main readon for loving it is that it creates a rich and vibrant world for you to explore and investigate.  The characters are all distinguishable and I mean for god's sake the main evil guy is absolutely hilarious.  A dentist who removes brains I mean I wish I could come up with that.  There a about nine different psychic abilities that you get in the game and each one just as important as the others at some point.  Some you use more than others but each a joy to use.  The envirmonments are mainly different characters imaginations and each one is so unique making the experience believable and intriguing.  Environments outside the mind are also well done but the creativity shines when you enter a persons mind to battle their demons.  All in all the humor, story, environments, and gameplay are all fantastic.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: A brilliant platformer that really surprised me. I had played Psychonauts briefly on PS2 but picked it up on Steam sale with the intentions of finishing it someday. After I started the game, I couldn't stop playing! The writing in Psychonauts is what sets it apart but the tight controls, varied level designs, and artwork are all great too. As you learn new psychic abilities, you'll use them to reach new areas but it doesn't feel like a locked off area akin to a Metroid or Zelda game. Anyone with an interest in how the world looks to other people and battles of the mind would love this game and it's worth the retail price easily!

reviewText: Loved this. Awesome storyline, great environment, lots of fun stuff to collect. It's worth noting (if you're into achievements) that many of them are entirely missable, also that it goes dark part way through the game making finding stuff outside much harder and there is no free roaming after you finish the game so you will be wanting to grab everything as you go along. Having said that, exploring in between everything you do will allow you happen across many funny little things that deserve not to be missed.

reviewText: Psychonauts is one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm glad it has finally come to Mac (and gotten Steam achievements)! This isn't the best platformer ever, but it's not bad. Combined with the various psychic powers you get throughout the game, it makes for a lot of fun. It's not super difficult most of the way through. (The final level is notoriously difficult, but supposedly they toned its difficulty back with the Mac release; I don't know yet, I haven't made it that far since the Mac release came out.)\nThe graphics are a little dated now, but the art styles are very fun. Every mind is different with its own unique styles. It's also a very well-written game, story-wise. Be sure to take time to go through it; they've put in all sorts of little details, including ones I didn't even realize were in there until I had to go hunting for them from the achievements!

reviewText: Combining a hilarious story, an original world, and tight gameplay, Psychonauts is a brilliant example of how to do a modern" platformer.\n\nMechanics:The gameplay is basically a more refined version of your classic
date: Super Mario 64-style platforming. You run and jump around a 3D world
recommended: gaining new abilities over time that allow you to meet new challenges and explore the world in new ways. The classic double jump and hover are represented
hoursPlayed: allowing you to reach otherwise inaccessible platforms
voteText: but there's also a super cool sprint mechanic. Not only does it let you zip around the world really fast once you unlock it
helpfulPercent: but it also functions as a combat weapon and it can be chained seamlessly into a hover mode. It's really clever.\n\nThe combat works better than you usually see in platformers
votesHelpful: which allows Double Fine to include lots of fun little combat challenges and boss fights without it becoming frustrating. There are multiple combat powers to pick from
votesTotal: but you can only bind a few to hotkeys
votesFunny: so it forces players to pick a "build" that they want to use as their go-to combat choice. However
commentsCount: there are also specific challenges that require you to think about your other powers and realize that you can rotate between your entire arsenal in order to solve problems.\n\nLevel Design:Mind-blowingly good. A platformer lives or dies based on how well its levels are designed - they need to be fun to navigate
column16: have interesting puzzles to solve
column17: and provide good flow to the gameplay. Psychonauts checks off all these boxes with style.\n\nIt also employs one of the most unique hooks to its levels I've ever seen. You have the overworld
column19: but then all the other levels take place inside people's minds
column20: with their individual psyche dictating the makeup of the level. This gives each level a completely unique feel and provides the opportunity for all sorts of challenges to be immersed in the game world
column21: when they would usually feel artificial.\n\nLater on
column22: you start going inside the minds of people with mental disorders
column23: which gives each level a deliberately uncanny feel and presents all sorts of interesting challenges. Oh
column24: and there's also a giant fish whose mind is full of peaceful little fish cities being terrorized by a Godzilla-like human.\n\nThe levels are full of collectibles
column25: in the spirit of the old collectathon platformers like Banjo-Kazooie. They're all optional and provide varying degrees of enjoyment. The mental vaults and scavenger hunt are the best
column26: while the figments are what it looks like when a developer *wants* to torture someone.\n\nMost of the game is spent gradually teaching you new mechanics
column27: spacing the tutorial out over loads of fun story stuff
column28: but then the very last level presents you with a hard mastery challenge that forces you to use all the skills you've learned at a high degree of mastery.\n\nNarrative:Raz runs away from the circus to join a summer camp for psychics. While there
column29: he tries to impress the instructors and convince them that he has what it takes to become a psychonaut - a psychic secret agent. Along the way
column30: he uncovers a sinister plot at the heart of the camp
column31: and it falls to him to put a stop to it.\n\nThis is the highlight of the game. Yes
column33: but it's even funnier to experience. It's co-written by Tim Schafer
column34: a veteran of Lucasarts adventure games
column36: who is famous for writing the dialogue of the Portal games. With those two behind the story
column37: it'd be shocking if Psychonauts *wasn't* hilarious.\n\nAll the dialogue is master-class. All the characters are phenomally well-realized. And the story itself is both funny and intriguing
column38: with little bits of foreshadowing planted as early as the first tutorial level
column39: so that the mystery of the evil plot builds slowly over the game
column40: but makes perfect senese once revealed. Then there's the adorable romance between Raz and Lili
column41: which manages to tug at my heart strings even though it's relatively light.\n\nThe levels present a textbook on environmental storytelling
column42: with their very design communicating volumes about the personality of the person whose mind you are in. Add in the mental vaults and secret areas
column43: and you have the *level design* by itself telling a deeper story than many entire games do.\n\nThe main story is mostly about a coming of age and realization of potential
column44: and Raz's struggle to find acceptance from his father. We see Raz run away from his family in order to prove himself and pursue the career he's always wanted
column45: and by learning to fix other people's nightmares and insecurities
column46:
he also learns to face his own.

Aesthetics:Fantastic. Every last bit.

The art direction is stunning
column47: providing both a unique feel and cohesive style for the world
column48: while also giving each of the mind levels a wildly different
column49: unique style that is unique unto itself and communicates that person's mental state. It's really impressive. Double Fine basically asked its artists to do the same amount of design work usually required for several different games
column50: just so they could make one great game.\n\nPeter McConnel's soundtrack is fantastic
column51: providing lots of upbeat and jangly platforming music as well as deeper
column52: dramatic scores for story moments.\n\nThe voice acting deserves special mention. Every single character is well-voiced
column53: which is an incredibly rare feat among video games. There are no phoned-in or C-list performances. The entire cast is full of different personalities

reviewText: I bought Psychonauts after I was amazed by storyline and everything of Brutal Legend, another game by Double Fine. And even though I wasn't so enthusiastic at the beginning, I can tell that it's probably the second best game I played this year (well, I mostly play older games, nevermind), after aforementioned Brutal Legend. The story is just fantastic, there are tons of collectibles (which I really like in every game) and intelligent humor. Even graphics is quite good as for game released in 2005, but it's the least important thing. Oh, and I forgot to mention the voices are just epic (Sheegor voice is masterpiece). Game is almost perfect, but well, the controls are definetely not perfect. I used mouse and keyboard, but still it was sometimes hard to move between menus. I also had some problems with camera, especially in narrower places, like small rooms or caves. Everything else is perfect. Except the fact that after 8 years there's still no Psychonauts 2. I still hope that cash I spent on this game will one day make my dream of Psychonauts 2 come true.\n\nOh, almost forgot: MR. POKEYLOPE IS MY KING, LALALA EVERYTHING

reviewText: Psychonauts is a game that stands on its setting. First off, the environment is wonderfully designed. The setting is a summer camp for psychics, and the everyday beauty of nature is distorted by the childlike playfulness ofthe supernatural elements. Boardwalks don't just wind down forest paths, but undulate through space, twisting and turning like something out of a Tim Burton film. The characters are engaging and bizarre, their quirks lovingly detailed, both in appearance and characterization, making everyone unique. There are no generic background characters" in this game; every character has a backstory

reviewText: Yep, Psychonauts is good. The levels are varied and interesting. The writing is funny. There's a lot of fun, different mechanics/abilities to use. It's an action-adventure with lots of platforming. Judging jumps can be a little tricky in 3D. This made part of the end of the game really more frustrating than it should have been, but that didn't mar the experience much. 20 minutes of 20 hours sucked. There is a bit of puzzle solving in the game. The graphics of course look a bit dated now, but the art style still really helps the look of the game hold up over time and it was often pretty to look at. Overall, Psychonauts is a really well put together game. I was impressed.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game to pieces! I would recommend it to everyone! Especially to people who have a sense of humor (or dark humor, whichever one you perfer). Even though it plays better on the original Xbox, I don't think anyone should miss playing this game at all on the PC... I would also recommend a USB controller to play; it's well worth it.

As for the story, it revolves around a young psychic named Raz, who ran away from his home to pursue his dream of becoming a Psychonaut, who are an organization of psychics who help out in various other things around the world. He ends up at Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp, where they train people to become Psychonauts, and is also a summer camp for psychic children. But, all is not right at the camp, and it is up to Raz to stop a dastardly plan that will threaten the world!

... Anyway, that's my little summary of the story without spoiling too much. :B

So, in other words... Get this game. Now! :U

reviewText: For the first game of Double Fine to be released, I'd say this one was a great starting point. Unique story, creative worlds, amazing characters, and a beautiful musical score can show how great this game truly is. However, slightly stiff controls and a weird camera can ruin the game, and most of the side quests are just incredibly long collect-a-thons. However, if you enjoy a good mind-dive, then this is a game I'd recommend. Just don't drink the milk.

reviewText:
Psychonauts is quite possibly the best platform game I have ever played. In this game, you play as Razputin (or Raz for short), a child acrobat that has ran away from the circus to become a psychonaut, an agent with psionic powers that is able to travel through one’s mind and cure them of their trauma or mental illness. The superpower available are marksmanship (which is Raz’s range attack) telekinesis, pyrokinesis, shield, invisibility, levitation, clairvoyance (which allows Raz to see through the eyes of the NPCs), and confusion.

All of these psionic powers are not just something Raz can do: they ALL have a purpose in the game. The use of certain psionic powers is required to progress further into the game. As I played this game, repetition was at a minimum as the objectives for each level are NEVER reused. Each of the game’s bosses have different strategies in order to defeat them, so you’ll never feel like you’re fighting the same boss twice.

Razputin actually happens to be voiced by Richard Steven Horvitz, the same voice actor the provided the voice of Invader Zim. Psychonauts was designed by Tim Schafer, who also designed the critical successes yet commercial failures Grim Fandango and Brütal Legend. Just like these two games, Psychonauts was a critical success, but a commercial failure. Out of all the platform video games I’ve played, Psychonauts definitely has the most innovation, which is one of my two favorite words when it comes to video games (the other being “variety”).

While I absolutely adore this game, there were only two problems I had with it: one was that the common enemy known as the censor was pretty overused in much of the game. There is also a character called Sheegor who has just the most annoying voice (fortunately, Sheegor doesn’t appear in most of the game)! Another problem I had with this game is it kept crashing (possible due to it being an older game). However, I was able to find a solution and you can find it by clicking  here.

For the great game that Psychonauts is, I would love see a sequel. Markus Persson (the creator of Minecraft) had even offered to fund the sequel, but later changed his mind. Unlike most platform games, Psychonauts is not designed specifically for kids as it was rated T by the ESRB for crude humor and language. The game has usually minor swear words and some of the game’s jokes did make me laugh a little. If you have not checked out this game, I strongly suggest that you do so. If there was a sequel, I would certainly pay full retail price for it.

reviewText: Psychonauts is a classic. While often described as a platformer it really is just another way for Tim Schaeffer to tell a story as he always has, this time through a hub world action platformer rather than a point-and-click adventure. As confident and compelling protagonist Raz you explore the minds of others to learn more about yourself all the while building and adding new psychic powers to your repertoire. If you like action and adventure with some platforming thrown in Psychonauts will gladly scratch that itch and have you coming back for more. With full controller support and achievements this is a must own for any Steam gamer.

reviewText: I'm pretty sure that nobody is kidding when they say that Psychonauts is an underrated classic, and neither am I. In terms of gameplay, it could use some polish - the combat can admittedly get repetitive and the platforming can get frustrating, especially in the notorious Meat Circus - but what truly makes this game great is everything else. The character design is wonderfully weird and oddly endearing. I could probably count on one hand the number of characters with believable skin and hair colors, but even with their odd proportions and designs, I couldn't help but love people like potato-shaped Coach Oleander and stick-thin Fred. The levels and overworld are filled with detail and little tidbits that add charm and personality. And the story! And the CHARACTERS! My friends, you will believe that a giant mutated lungfish can be a magical lady. You will find yourself aww"-ing over a Brazilian disco girl and her German mad scientist crush. You will bawl your eyes out upon discovering their pasts. You will find yourself weirdly intrigued with the story of a summer camp filled with a bunch of strange campers and counselors
recommended: and the little kid wearing goggles that barges in one day and saves the world. But most of all
hoursPlayed: you will laugh. A lot. I have no problem calling this game the funniest of all time. No go play it. Your delightfully deranged adventure is waiting."

reviewText: Psychonauts is a PS2-era action platformer. Developed by Double Fine and originally published by Majesco, it was released in 2005 for the Xbox, and 2006 for the PC and Playstation 2.It was reviewed well, but sold poorly, and has garnered a cult following. It's not an old game, but a lot has changed since it came out. Let's see how it holds up today.\n\nIt stars the young wanna-be Psychonaut" Razputin
date: commonly referred to as "Raz." Razputin sneaks into a camp for gifted children
hoursPlayed: and no. Not that kind. These kids have mind powers. Like
voteText: burning things. With their minds!) but is caught by the

votesTotal: I guess. One of them looks like Resetti. Anyway
votesFunny: they want to send Raz home
commentsCount: but are unable to contact his parents. So they let him stay. And things start to get weird. Like
column16: kids having their brains removed and walking around like zombies weird.\n\nThe plot is good enough
column18: but it is charming and well written. The creativity behind the game is exceptional. Levels all take place in people's heads. Literally. Raz gets sucked into their brain through a tiny door. It's basically Extreme Makeover: Therapy Edition. You help people with their mental health
column19: in the most fun way possible. No two levels are the same
column20: just like people's minds. And just like the levels

column23: a descendant of Napoleon with split-personality disorder
column24: and a friendly psychic mutant angler-fish. Every character's level reflects their personality
column27: and interesting.\n\nThere's not much more to be said about Psychonauts without giving spoilers. This is truly one of those games that you are better off jumping in head first with reckless abandon. Don't look anything up about this game. You'll thank me later."

reviewText: The most creative game I have ever played.  I absolutely loved this game for many different reasons but I think my main readon for loving it is that it creates a rich and vibrant world for you to explore and investigate.  The characters are all distinguishable and I mean for god's sake the main evil guy is absolutely hilarious.  A dentist who removes brains I mean I wish I could come up with that.  There a about nine different psychic abilities that you get in the game and each one just as important as the others at some point.  Some you use more than others but each a joy to use.  The envirmonments are mainly different characters imaginations and each one is so unique making the experience believable and intriguing.  Environments outside the mind are also well done but the creativity shines when you enter a persons mind to battle their demons.  All in all the humor, story, environments, and gameplay are all fantastic.

reviewText: A brilliant platformer that really surprised me. I had played Psychonauts briefly on PS2 but picked it up on Steam sale with the intentions of finishing it someday. After I started the game, I couldn't stop playing! The writing in Psychonauts is what sets it apart but the tight controls, varied level designs, and artwork are all great too. As you learn new psychic abilities, you'll use them to reach new areas but it doesn't feel like a locked off area akin to a Metroid or Zelda game. Anyone with an interest in how the world looks to other people and battles of the mind would love this game and it's worth the retail price easily!

reviewText: Psychonauts is the quirkiest of quirky games.  From the art styles to the different worlds you explore to the dialoge of the main characters & NPCs.  The story is especially quirky.  You jump into other Psychonauts' minds to learn new psychic abilities.  For some reason your own mind is being intruded by meat.  Yes, meat.  and you have to figure out why.  My favorite characters are the not-so-secret-agents in one world.  They all have the same male, monotone voice, but everything they say is amusing.  When you get the Clairvoyance psychic power you can use it on people, animals, and random objects to see yourself through their eyes.  For example: Rats would see you as cheese, and the mailboxes see you as a person covered in question marks..  Yeah, it's weird.   This game is a Must Play and has great Replayability

reviewText: This game is probably the most frustrating yet still lovable game I've played in the last few years. I'm sure if I had played the game when it came out the clunky platforming wouldn't have been as frustrating (okay yea it would be but at least I would be used to it) but it still didn't hinder the gameplay all that much (except when it bugged out during a boss). It reminded me of the platformers from when I was a kid and had charming humor you just don't see anymore. Raz is a spunky little kid who is joined by a colorful (and colorful MOUTHED) class of superpowered children who need a better adult than they got at camp.\n\nThe story is wonderfully told through the minds" of some eccentric people and through the eyes of a naive and hopeful child. It's sure to throw you for a loop and back again. The art style is off putting at first because of the weird and just purposely ugly designs but they grow on you. The levels are just beautiful (especially Black Velvetopia) and I've never seen anything like them before. They make your head spin and frustrate you
date: but it's all a part of the fun.\n\nThe only bad parts of this game I think are the clunky outdated controls making it hard to platform
hoursPlayed: the final level Meat Circus... even the achievement says "i thought that was unbeatable" and for a slow computer it is!
voteText: and let's not forget the monotonous collecting of all figments.\n\nBut it does have replay value if you miss some things
helpfulPercent: you just won't want to 100% it again. It's unforgettable dialogue and one of a kind cast really leave a lasting impression on you. I'm glad I got to play it first as an adult because I wouldn't have gotten half the jokes 10 years ago. I think it would do well to have a remake (or at least remaster with better controls) because I already miss this game. I'll be playing again some day."

reviewText: Psychonauts is one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm glad it has finally come to Mac (and gotten Steam achievements)! This isn't the best platformer ever, but it's not bad. Combined with the various psychic powers you get throughout the game, it makes for a lot of fun. It's not super difficult most of the way through. (The final level is notoriously difficult, but supposedly they toned its difficulty back with the Mac release; I don't know yet, I haven't made it that far since the Mac release came out.)\nThe graphics are a little dated now, but the art styles are very fun. Every mind is different with its own unique styles. It's also a very well-written game, story-wise. Be sure to take time to go through it; they've put in all sorts of little details, including ones I didn't even realize were in there until I had to go hunting for them from the achievements!

reviewText:
This is the best 3D PC platformer after American McGee's Alice.

Platformers are a dying genre. This was one of the last great ones (the last I can honestly think of, of any note was Alice: Madness Returns, sequel to the aforementioned, also recommended). Highest Recommendation.

reviewText:
Intro & SummaryPsychonauts is a fun journey and romp as a kid at a psychic summer camp, learning psychic powers and using them to explore a fun story, and equally fantastically designed world.
Clocking in at 13 hours, but has such a surprisingly rich and detailed main story that you'll likely clock in at least double that.

HighlightsThe core of a good single player is it's storyline or arc. This game, hands down, has the best I've ever played. You care enough about the characters to drive you forward, humour is packed everywhere, and is mature and funny, little details, easter eggs and extras are scattered anywhere you can think of. I routinely come back and run through this game every couple years, and find new things I completely missed the last time.

MistakesHonestly, practically none. You could argue that one of the few thousand set pieces are flawed slightly to make a challenging section frustrating, or go wrong once or twice, but even that is a stretch on what is pretty much a perfectly designed and polished game, which somehow still feels quirky and personal.

BuyingPsychonauts is routinely available for $5 or less, and has even hit as low as $1 on Steam and Indie Bundles. It will not leave you feeling like a jerk after paying full price, and given the quality and fun it's worth at least that.

reviewText:
It took me a while to find this game, and when I did find it, I wasn't in a rush to buy it, as the screenshots on the store page didn't appeal to me that much. I ended up buying it with a few other games, not in a bundle, just together. I left it in my library for a few months, and I got bored and played it.... And I didn't stop until I finished it.

You will regret your purchase of this game, but the part you will regret is not the money, but the time in which you waited until you played it. I know I regret it, I regret that I didn't find this game earlier, that I didn't play it WHEN it came out. But it's not too late to play, and the game has aged quite well (not that it was that old anyway).

What makes this game so good that I am building it up so much? Everything about it is good.

The whole theme of this game is insanity and telepathy. These themes are darkly and nicely woven into the levels and into the game. Going into other people's minds and seeing dark recesses of insane asyulms. Characters who are strange and twisted, phycopaths, Narcissists, multiple personalities, suicidal children, etc. The characters in this game will not disapoint, especially not Mr. Pokeylope. ;)

The graphics stlyes are different depending on environment, which gives a very nice feeling to the game. It can be very dark and colourful, and go to being very bright and cheery. Which makes it practically impossibe to completely hate the stlye of the game, if you don't like the dark levels, you'll like the bright levels, but sometimes, you like all the levels.

There is very little wrong with this game, some achievements are hard to get (but that's a plus), but other than that, you have little reason to not buy this game and play it. It is sitting up as one of my favourite (if not favourite) game. It was just such an enjoyable experience to play, and it's one that doesn't seem to be played by as many as it should be.

reviewText: Simply one of the best 3D platformers I have ever played. The story is great, the controls are tight, the level design is amazing and full of imagination. This is not a game you want to miss out on. This classic hidden treasure is definitely worth your time and your money. The concept of traveling through peoples minds to solve their emotional problems is really fun, especially considering that the people you have to help are either crazy, have mental issues or had bad childhoods. Oh and did I mention the amazing writing? Everything you hear a character say is either interesting or funny.\n\nDefinitely a game you need to play if you're into classic 3D platformers. This game is a masterpiece. 9/10

reviewText:
Modern gamers may not appreciate this game as much as original Xbox owners.

With that said, I actually had this game originally on the Xbox and it was one of the less-heard-of but more fantastic games I had played for Xbox (Alongside Blinx, and both games were 'only for xbox' to begin with). Years later I find this game on steam and it made my heart flutter - the controls are a little wonky with the keyboard, definately, but simple enough to use when you bind everything to what you're more comfortable with!

The plot is captivating and the artistic style this game holds is very unique. It's usually an open-world exploration type with its gameplay, and the plot usually isn't very hard to follow but players have been known to get stuck here and there (especially when using the button item to meet Sasha).

The graphics aren't the greatest but there was certainly a lot of detail put into its scenery and surroundings. Its levels are unique and colorful and overall appealing to the eye.

Definatley one of my all-time favorites.

reviewText:
Whenever I think about this game I get a tear in my eye because this is one of the most inspired games I've ever seen.. 9.5/10

Every level is unique and revolves around a few specific psychic abilities that you're given. What's neat about the abilities is that for most of them, you don't use only one for a level and then stop using it for the rest of the game. Each ability has its place in plenty of areas, from when you get it to the game's end. (The same kind of applies to the items you're given/you buy, many levels have extra goodies for you to go back and obtain with them!)

The gameplay is super super fun but the camera can get a bit wonky at times, especially during levels that require elevation(like the area above the theatre level, which made me lose my sh*t :^) )

The characters are all excellently characterized and the game does a very good job of thawing out their backstories. Another thing about the characters is they're all incredibly memorable; each and every one of them have fitting (and very talented, may I add) voice actors and unique designs that it's almost hard to forget any of them. (*Note: I am the Milkman.)

I remember almost every scene from this game, and I mean maybe that's because it's only been 2-3 months since I've played it buuut I do believe I'll still remember them a year or two from now. Especially Goggalor... GOGGALOR!!!!!

To be entirely honest, this is probably one of the best games I have ever played. If I had to give it a personal ranking, it's probably either my second or third favorite video game of all time beside Kingdom Hearts 2.

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ guys please, if you're reading this and you're genuinly interested in getting this game, by all means do it. It's definitely worth the price and you will put a good amount of hours into it, especially if you go for a bit of achievement hunting like I did. It'll also make you more excited for the upcoming sequel!!!(which I'm super super hyped for!)

It's escapism at it's best and if you love video games you will love Psychonauts.

reviewText:
Hands-down favorite game.

Psychonauts is built on an incredibly unique concept: using psychic abilities to explore the minds of others. Literally, explore. Walking around in them.

Characters are infinitely entertaining, plot is engaging and hardly predictable, mechanics are smooth and uncomplicated.

Atmosphere is unlike any other, in part due to the characteristic art style of the game.

Levels are kind of short, but perfect length to keep the story moving so that you're not spending too much time in either the meta-world or the minds of others.

reviewText: One of my greatest PS2 favourites, I knew I had to have it as soon as I saw it on Steam. reviewText:
This is the best 3D PC platformer after American McGee's Alice.

Platformers are a dying genre. This was one of the last great ones (the last I can honestly think of, of any note was Alice: Madness Returns, sequel to the aforementioned, also recommended). The storyline is off-the-wall and involves you going into other people's minds. The levels are often surreal and design is outstanding. has lost none of its charm even today.

Highest Recommendation.

reviewText:
Psychonauts is a great game. Psychonauts has problems. The positives vastly outweigh the negatives.

To get my issues with it out of the way first:
- The platforming was difficult for me in parts prompting a lot of trial and error. This sounds like a small point but when the result is continuous repetition to make a  single jump it gets really annoying.
- Some enemies were difficult/annoying to fight.
- It's sad that you can't bind your powers to more buttons, as tabbing into the menu to swap powers out was just a little too much effort. It was released on the Xbox at the same time so you can see why this was done.

Okay now onto the positives:
- The story, the environments you find yourself in, the characters and the dialogue are all great. I can't stress this enough. The Steam trailer shows a range of levels of the game but it doesn't capture how excellent the dialogue and delivery is in this story where weird psychic kids go to summer camp.
- The graphical style still holds up. For a game over 10 years old, it's not difficult to watch.
- Collectibles matter. You level up almost exclusively through collectibles and several of them give you extra things to read/memories to watch. They're all very whimsically created and perfectly integrated into the game.
- Some real thought has been put into it. Example: the main character Razputin gives a reason as to why he can't swim (that normal video game limitation). They mention it several times and justify it. Nothing is done arbitrarily, making for a very solid world.
- It's a good length. Maybe 8 hours if you rush from place to place. Which you shouldn't do! Talk to as many other characters as possible, the dialogue is wonderful.

It's so close to being a game I would say young kids should definitely play (or watch being played). However there are some words I'd call 'not okay' used, and a few moments spring to mind which could be really scary for kids. The comedy gets dark at times. Make your own judgement if you're in that situation.

reviewText:
I remember preordering this game at gamestop when it came out in 2005. I played the HECK out of this games. It's littered with awesome puns and clever jokes! It can be challenging (in a good way!), yet surprisingly fun and easy to understand and adapt to. The game play time isn't too bad. I'd say maybe a little under 21 hours if you were just focused on the story. But if you're interested in completeing the game in its entirety by doing every sidequest and collecting everything there is, maybe 48 hours tops. I remember there being a LOT to do in the game, figments, emotional baggage, etc. Lots of things to collect. I HIGHLY reccommend this game and I am not afraid to judge you if you don't buy it. :p

P.S.
My favorite part is the summoning bacon <3

reviewText:
Psychonauts is a rather obscure game, let's start there.

You are Raz, a ten-year-old boy with psychic abilities at a summer camp for psychics, and it's your job to become a Psychonaut before your dad picks you up from camp. Sounds bad? Oh, you just wait.

Considering this is a 3-D platformer, I'll start at the platforming then. Unless your computer is complete poop and you lag on everything (even Microsoft Word, yes, I know. Soak in the badness) the response you get from jumping, climbing and...uhh...swinging around a pole and then launching yourself. Speaking of jumping, you can double jump.

Moving on from jumping on platforms, combat is the other third of this game (the last third is the stages, or 'minds' as they refer to in-game, since your 'levels' are you travelling into other people's minds, most of the time solving an issue they have or getting a power-up). You have your basic 1-2-3 karate chop then force palm combo and your 'palm bomb', a smashing attack when, you guessed it, slam into the ground with your palm (surprising, I know). Now to mention the multiple merit badges you earn to use other abilities, like setting things on fire or turning invisible. This allows you to come up with your own tactics against all enemies, let alone have some fun with non-combat abilities, like Clairvoyance, haha, always a blast to use.

(Oh god, that paragraph)

Anyway, I've rambled on for long enough. SO LET'S RAMBLE ON MORE!

Last, but definately not least, are the minds and psyche of the people you meet. Before I go in-depth and all, Edgar's mind, or Black Velvetopia, is my favourite mind, just so that's out of the way. Each level doesn't feel the same, and every mind has it's own theme, look and way to complete it. For example, in the very first stage, Coach Oleander's mind called 'Basic Braining', has you going through war, which in this case is a massive obstacle course. Might I add, even though this has nothing to do with the levels, is that the dialogue and humour in the game is absolute bliss.

Sadly, we come to the bad parts of the game. Uhh, sometimes for me, at least, (even though this only happened to me at the end of the game) the controls will just kinda cut out, leaving you with a falling Raz and a loss of your astral projection layer in the current mind you're in. Or just thrown into a very inconvenient spot. Also, (and also only at the end of the game) the camera direction can be kinda irritating at times. As in, the kind of WHERE AM I SUPPOSED TO GO?!" camera. This rarely happens and is only for small segments. Finally
date: enemies that you have no idea how to beat. This is a personal complaint and you can say
recommended: maybe a stupid one. I'm talking about enemies
hoursPlayed: particularly bosses
voteText: that you have no idea how to beat and you're left with something kicking your ♥♥♥ and there's nothing you can do about it. This is the biggest complaint here

reviewText:
This is the best 3D PC platformer after American McGee's Alice.

Platformers are a dying genre. This was one of the last great ones (the last I can honestly think of, of any note was Alice: Madness Returns, sequel to the aforementioned, also recommended). The storyline is off-the-wall and involves you going into other people's minds. The levels are often surreal and design is outstanding. has lost none of its charm even today.

Highest Recommendation.

reviewText:
With a sequel on it's way, years of hearing positive review, and the high recommendation from Psychonauts biggest fanboy, James from Funhaus, I finally picked up the game. Does this decade old game hold up to all the hype? Yes, yes it does.

Negative
- Weird yet awesome Menu with too many game features on it
- Big subtitles
- Slows down around the 3rd act
- Can't go back to camp after the point of no return (for collectables)

Postives
- Amazing characters that hooks you to it's universe
- Unique artstyle
- Diverse level design with fun and complementary gameplay
- Voice acting and sound design
- Topnotch and still relvent humor
- Immersive story that leaves a huge gap for a sequel
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This was...a truly wondeful game. Initially, I first came across Physconauts as a picture, one of those random pictures that sometimes appear on google images for some reason or another, intrigued by the oddball style of character design, I looked further into the game, and I was struck by it's capacity to keep you interested. The music for all stages reflected well not only upon the mind of who you were exploring, with each person's mind receiving a unique piece.\nThe character designs are not based on traditional aesthetic values, but still create a diverse cast who, while a great many of them are barely mentioned in the actual plot, are prominent in the many little side affairs that make up camp life (which I found created a realisticness in a place where not too many would expect it).\nOne of the main things I really liked about the game was the exploration factor, in that, the Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp proved a vast place to poke, jump, burn, and run around, in fact, a moderate chunk of late game fighting capacity relies on your exploration. Interestingly enough, Psychonauts doesn't rely on overt violence to keep you entertained, although there usually is mental censors of some kind to fight through as minor obstacles in most minds. Instead, you must explore through various places, figuring out how to best get around (One case being how to go up a street without being run over by a bull.) That isn't to say the boss fights aren't challenging. Far from it, as the boss fights I've encountered here, rely not on overt violence, but rather figuring out how to use various psychic powers to exploit the enemy's weakness and win from there. Combine this with amusing dialogue, jokes for all ages, and minor plot arcs which lead one to speculation about real life people based on fictional characters, and many other things which make the Game of Psychonauts a Must Play.

reviewText:
Progression is rather linear, but it is actually fun. Everything about the game is unique, from the art style to most of the abilities to the characters to the dialogue. Black Velvetopia especially is a beautiful piece of art. Wonderful game all around but is also has minor annoyances.

For example, the mouse and keyboard combination takes getting used too and some parts of the game are down right infuriating with them. Small parts of stages have awful design (I'm looking at the Waterloo mainly). Found myself exploiting the hell out of levitation.

Still, I highly recommend this game.

NOTE: If you are using Windows 7, I recommend going to Psychonauts.exe > Properties and sticking it in Compatibility mode with Windows 95. The game up until Gloria's Theater ran fine, but then the graphics started messing up and the fps hit the fan. Doing the above fixed it and I encounter no issues past that.

reviewText:
Hands-down favorite game.

Psychonauts is built on an incredibly unique concept: using psychic abilities to explore the minds of others. Literally, explore. Walking around in them.

Characters are infinitely entertaining, plot is engaging and hardly predictable, mechanics are smooth and uncomplicated.

Atmosphere is unlike any other, in part due to the characteristic art style of the game.

Levels are kind of short, but perfect length to keep the story moving so that you're not spending too much time in either the meta-world or the minds of others.

reviewText:
Whenever I think about this game I get a tear in my eye because this is one of the most inspired games I've ever seen.. 9.5/10

Every level is unique and revolves around a few specific psychic abilities that you're given. What's neat about the abilities is that for most of them, you don't use only one for a level and then stop using it for the rest of the game. Each ability has its place in plenty of areas, from when you get it to the game's end. (The same kind of applies to the items you're given/you buy, many levels have extra goodies for you to go back and obtain with them!)

The gameplay is super super fun but the camera can get a bit wonky at times, especially during levels that require elevation(like the area above the theatre level, which made me lose my sh*t :^) )

The characters are all excellently characterized and the game does a very good job of thawing out their backstories. Another thing about the characters is they're all incredibly memorable; each and every one of them have fitting (and very talented, may I add) voice actors and unique designs that it's almost hard to forget any of them. (*Note: I am the Milkman.)

I remember almost every scene from this game, and I mean maybe that's because it's only been 2-3 months since I've played it buuut I do believe I'll still remember them a year or two from now. Especially Goggalor... GOGGALOR!!!!!

To be entirely honest, this is probably one of the best games I have ever played. If I had to give it a personal ranking, it's probably either my second or third favorite video game of all time beside Kingdom Hearts 2.

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ guys please, if you're reading this and you're genuinly interested in getting this game, by all means do it. It's definitely worth the price and you will put a good amount of hours into it, especially if you go for a bit of achievement hunting like I did. It'll also make you more excited for the upcoming sequel!!!(which I'm super super hyped for!)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It had been a while since I played the original PS2 Psychonauts and beat it, possibly a couple years at most. Since I beat it I always had that elusive Rank 101 in mind, having only gotten somewhere around 70-90. Now that I rebought the game I spent a good three consecutive days hunting everything down and getting the ***** to display my name and call me a psychomaster. It got a little frustrating from time to time when I couldn't find the last collectable in a few worlds as they hid in plain sight, but overall... I liked the game. I kinda wished that some of the characters were a little more fleshed out, but for what it is I enjoy it. If you do play this game, don't just rush through it (Unless your goal is to go fast). Instead, take your time and explore the world a few times, you might witness things you didn't expect. Getting all the achievements on Steam really showed me how much of this game I didn't see before. So many new things to do and learn about that my mind was boggled by the sheer amount of stuff.

Aim for the highest rank possible, but if you get stuck wondering how to do that *ONE* thing, or where the last collectable is... It isn't necessarily the best idea to get yourself worked up trying to figure it out.
Okay, spoilers.

SPOILERS TO SOME DEGREE:


In the end, it ends up being a bit disappointing that there really isn't any... bonus, for Rank 101. You do get something for rank 100, but not 101. Well, you get the achievement but that's it. Not really worth it in my opinion, but I guess it's the journey that counts.

GET THIS GAME!
You can enter crazy people's minds, and become a psychic agent. It's like X-Men mixed with Invader Zim.
What powers does Razputin have? I don't know... how about the power of levitation!? How about MIND BULLETS?!
Bacon is one of your items, and it helps with hints plus teleportations. Use it once you get it.
This game is literally up there with Kingdom Hearts and Super Mario Bros. LITERAL BRAIN EXPLODING. In a good way.

The ONLY reason i bought Broken Age and Brutal Legend was cause i figured it help fund Psychonauts 2. You wanna know how much i want Psychonauts 2? It is quite a lot!
All I'd want is a similar setup as the first game, but with enhanced combat and acrobatics. Bonus points if several playable characters, multiplayer, and anything else.

That's all, not much of an official review. Just wanted to say my thoughts.

reviewText:
One of the best platform/adventure games I've ever played. Reminded me a lot of the awesome Rare days of Banjo-Kazooie, Conker and Donkey Kong 64. I'm not saying this game is like those, it certainly has the qualities of a platform game; jumping puzzles, collectibles, abilities that help you overcome new obstacles. But it executes those things in a way that is different from those other games.

The game deals with psychic powers and travelling through the minds and dreams of others. You will get different psychic powers, some of which are awesome to use all the time, that will let you access different areas and overcome different enemies while travelling throuh the minds of people and dealing with their fears and issues which will transform into monsters that you will have to defeat.

The story is hilarious, the characters are so cool and memorable, the Milkman comes to mind. The art style is pretty freaky, everything looks otherwordly and rightly so, as you will mostly be travelling the dreams inside the minds of your friends.

I truly recommend this game to anyone who likes adventure games and weird, unique wrolds with very funny stories and characters.

Do play with a controller, it is much more enjoyable in this game to do so.

reviewText:
Platform games come in many shapes and sizes. There are the big-name platforming mainstays, such as Mario and Sonic, that rely on their own brand of rules and obstacles to overcome. You have the run-and-gunners, the hop-n-bops, the Metroidvanias, the collect-a-thons, those with realistic physics, the platform hells, the list goes on and on...

However, there is a rare breed of platformer that comes out every so often that defies many of the traditional sub-genre aspects and manages to be it's own unique experience.

Psychonauts is one of those games.

The story of the begins with Raz running away from home to become a Psychonaut, a kind of mixture between a secret agent and mental projectionist. He is taken in by the training camp, set into a journey that has him entering mind after bizarre mind to solve a sinister brain stealing plot.

With mental focus being the theme of the game, Raz learns many useful abilities such as levitation, telekinesis, and even seeing how others see the world. Upgrades and useful items are everywhere and the unique locals make the exploring the various mindsets to be all the more enjoyable. The humor is also some of the most well-written and goes hand-in-hand with the stylized look. One could easily picture a Nicktoon based on the game.

Infamously bombing on it's intially release, it's earned a new life as time went on. For those looking for a unique 3D platformer on the PC, this is the first stop.

reviewText: It has been a long long time since i have fallen in love with a video game so quickly. I only recently finished my playthrough of Psychonauts, and i loved every little minute of it. Previously, i had heard many say that Psychonauts was an underappreciated hidden gem, that deserved so much more. To be honest i thought these people were simply over exaggerating the greatness of this game. As i soon learned my opinion was that of a fool's. Psychonauts blew me away as I began to play it. From the very beginning i knew that i would love this game, and its estetic. One of the very first things i noticed right away was visually, how everything looked. There is a distinct style that every character, and environment has: Nothing has perfect edges and corners. Everything has a slight bend, or at a peculiar angle, but is not to the point where it is jarring to the eyes, or unpleasant. This gives the game a unique look, that is not easily duplicated. Every environment seems different from the last, with it's own singular theme, that makes it look as though it could stand on its own. I enjoy this, because different places and levels SHOULD be solitary in their style. Different characters personalities reflect their their subconscious, giving you the true impression that you are in THIS person's mind. And each character has their own distinct personality, from the kids in the camp, to the coaches teaching. They all have a trait, or something more to them that grants them lots of... I guess the best way to describe it would be quirkiness. There is just something to them... I just love the way they act, the things they talk about, actions, responses, jokes, etc. Many a time have i been playing this game with a giant ♥♥♥♥ eating grin on my face, because of something somone did.  All of the characters in this game, even the protaganists, and enemies, are lovable. However the most lovable of all is your main character Razz (can't remember if im spelling that right). He somehow captures the essence of childlike wonder, and reminds me alot of myself when i was a kid. He somehow just has this... draw to him, somehting about him that makes you proud to play as him as you progress to the story, you see his character grow immensly. Moving right along to the story, I won't say much, you can watch the trailer if you want a preview, but I'll leave it at this. I couldn't  stop playing. I wanted to see what would happen next; who's mind I would enter, I just wanted more and more and more. I was entranced in the deep and moving narrative. Even at the end of the game, i found myself wanting more, and was genuinely sad when i realized I was probably on the final level. This was partly established because of the story, but also because of how engaging and fun the gameplay was. You utilize your own psychic abilities, which you earn via merrit badges. You earn these throughout the story, and by occasionally ranking up (which can be done by various means.) Every ability has their own time and place, and unlike most games (cough cough Tomb Raider reboot) you dont learn a certain ability and then never use it in the game ever again. There's always a time and place for  to a certain ability, and all of them are useful. Now some of these abilities are combat based, others movement or puzzle based. Psychonauts blends solid platforming with puzzle solving (I'm not really talking Legend of Zelda style puzzles, more puzzles you need to use your head to solve. Yes that pun was intended), along with a banjo Kazooie esque exploration. Along with fun combat and a ton of collectables to... collect. There is a lot to do in Psychonauts,  one can spend hours engaged in this masterpiece. However, this game is not that difficult, I didnt have that hard a time playing through it. There are moments where it has its difficulties, sometimes it may be vague (but this isnt too jarring or game breaking. Just a little difficulty finding where or what one must do to progress. I only had this problem once). But on the upside no major glitches, or save problems, etc.  Personally i love this game, and i knew it after about 20 minutes of playing. So i was thouroughly happy when i got more than my money's worth for a far longer game than i had expected. So am I here to tell you that Psychonauts is the most underrated games of the century and that Tim Shcafer is a god, like most of the internet (or people on the internet ive hear say that), no. I'm here to tell you that Psychonauts is a damn good game that I'm glad as hell glad I got it. And I'm not here to tell you its an underappreciated gem, I'm just here to tell you its a gem. I love it, and I'm sure you will too.\n

reviewText:
This is one of my all time favorite games and you should play it. I don't know what else to write so here is a recipe for the only thing I know of that is almost as good as this game

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup powdered sugar
1/2 cup creamy peanut butter
2 small boxes of instant vanilla pudding (home made pudding is better but instant is far easier)
1 (9-inch) gram cracker pie crust
2 cups whipped cream

Slightly adapted from The Amish Cook
DIRECTIONS:
in one bowl make pudding
in an other bowl mix peanut butter and powdered sugar until you have a bowl of little peanut butter nuggets.

After pudding is somewhat cool you can start to assemble the pie.

Add half the peanut butter nuggets to the bottom of the pie shell. Top with pudding. Add half the remaining peanut butter nuggets to the top of the pudding.

Top with whipped cream and remaining peanut butter nuggets.

Let the pie cool in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours to set up before cutting.
