reviewText:
---CONTAINS SPOILERS---

4/5 ☆

Having spent 30 odd hours on the game and finally unlocking all of the achievements, it's time for my honest opinion and review of Psychonauts.

A fascinating game with a somewhat odd, edging on bizarre story - but that's what's so appealing about it. It's a great 3D platformer that can keep you going for hours if you want to do everything 100%, with plenty of collectibles and secrets to uncover. If you like games like Ratchet and Clank, you'll enjoy this one.

The environments are vast and have plenty of exploration potential, some a bit more simple like the campgrounds and others considerably more complex like inside the minds of some of the characters you encounter, twisting and turning three-dimensionally around you. It's a great big basket of weird shaped fruit that you just want to dig into, fiddling and raising an eyebrow at each new stage's design and mechanics which in all comes together as a big ball of appealing 'wtf' that the game's story is in general. The music and sounds also help to fit in with this asylum theme of the game, they just seem to click nicely together and set the stage (pun quite literally intended in Gloria's mind) of that particular character's psyche, with the crazy and slightly disturbing nature of the last stage's music topping it all off.

The story seemed to escalate quickly, going from training and learning about your psychic powers to suddenly thwarting an evil brain snatching plot to take over the world. I suppose it again adds to the bizzaro charm of the game. You encounter along your way people with multiple personae, anger issues, traumatic events and resentment and the like. I find that sort of stuff very fascinating, even more so how they managed to get it to blend together in a story as it did.

It did however have it's fair share of negatives, though most are technical.

Crashes for example are a big issue. Within my first couple of hours in the game I had several rather annoying crashes as I tried to make my way up to the Basic Braining segment. The message of 'Psychnoats is not responding and needs to be shut down' popped up a fair few times on my journey through the game. I advise anyone interested in playing this game to SAVE VERY OFTEN - which isn't a bad practice to get into the habit of doing so anyway for any game. There are also instances where the game 'freezes' but doesn't crash. Watch out for these, as you can still play the game, as long as you don't fidget with your keyboard or controller. Basically, the screen will freeze, but the music may still play. Give it a few seconds and it will start moving again. It usually stutters a bit before this happens (at least in my experience), a decent indicator to quickly hit the save button!

Controls. You can play this game with a controller OR a keyboard and mouse. From the start, I would have preferred to use the controller, I believe given the type of game it is, it would have not only been easier to use a controller, but perhaps also more comfortable. However, there are teething issues with plugging in a controller. In my experience, it tended to crash MORE often when the controller was being used, and it had this strange issue where, even if you weren't touching the analogue sticks, Raz would start moving in a random direction, which also applied when operating the menus. I had to in the end unplug the USB receiver for the controller, shut down steam, re-launch and then play with the keyboard and mouse.

There are fixes I believe out there via forums and guides, I believe there may be one or two on Steam's community forums, and you can work around them. But the player shouldn't really have to go looking elsewhere for third party fixes when it should have been checked and double checked before throwing it out there by the producers of the game. I used the default keybinds throughout the game, and they were ok, but did feel a bit clustered and clumsy at times. Whether that was my own fault or not is up for debate, but in a frantic battle situation, I found myself constantly hitting the wrong key for my psychic power, or something like Telekinesis cutting out halfway and accidentally dropping the thing or enemy you were engaging with. Things like this I believe would be considerably easier if you used a controller. But you can always change the keybinds to whatever you prefer.

Now my biggest pain in the backside with this game. The camera. Oh my lord do I want to strangle that camera. It lets you down in places you need it most, such as to try and get an angle right for a jump, such as that 'don't drown' ascending acrobatic bit in the final boss area and that hovering spiralling segmented climable netting/mesh bit. That was the single most frutrating part of the whole finale, if not the whole game. It's smooth sailing with the odd bumps up until there and after it, but by God did that take me a while - because you had to wrestle with the camera WHILE attempting the difficult manoeuvre, a sort of manoeuvre you hadn't faced before in any earlier part of the game, and one that I adamantly believe cannot be done without deliberately taking damage from a burning section of the mesh in order to gain enough height to make the tricky jump.

When you want to look around to explore and scout out collectibles, you feel rather restricted. Even with high mouse sensitivity, I found myself having to skid the mouse over and over again to have a good look around and even then it seemed to move just as slow. It just adds unnecessary frustration when you're trying to enjoy and immerse yourself in the game's surroundings and puzzles. Again, I believe this wouldn't be an issue if you were to use a controller to play instead of the keyboard and mouse.

To finish off my criticisms (in case I start to inflate and turn purple, becoming a Jasper the Critic 2.0 and spit my popcorn at you), I'll have a quick snip at maps. In short: there aren't any! Ok, well, yes, there is one, for the campgrounds, an area that you won't be visiting as often after you can cross the lake, and an area you can't even return to after you hit the 'Point of No Return'. No other map. At all. For any other area. And yet, there is a MAP TAB on the main menu, which only displays as 'out of map range' when you're in any area other than the campgrounds. That was a bit disappointing in my opinion, a huge potential for additional exploration and aiding in finding collectibles was missed there.

Finally, the achievements in this game – be careful everyone! It's one of those games where after you hit a certain 'Point of No Return' – you won't be able to go back to some areas to collect stuff for some achievements, and you may miss some 'witness' achievements altogether unless you know when and where to go look for them in-between the different points of the story. I had to start another game from scratch to get the Pokeylope related achievement for example. I'd suggest making lots of separate saves  to help counter this.

To close, it's a weird and wonderful game that I enjoyed very much and would recommend to others. But to those others that are interested, I would strongly suggest you grab a controller and get that working properly – I believe it will make things a heck of a lot less frustrating and smoother to play with. As well as SAVING EVERY OTHER MINUTE to prevent getting setbacks from those nasty random crashes and freezes.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I've ever played- hands down, this game is a masterpiece. The story of this game is amazing, well thought through, and overwhelmingly humorous, and very challenging. It actually feels like the creators took more than 2 months like normal games do to make the plot. Overall I really cannot explain the plot in depth to give a great feeling, so just go enjoy it yourself. Psychonauts is also a giant game- leaving 48.2 hours of mine JUST for the story, and not for going back for the thousands of collectables this game has to offer.

What some people assume and will assume is the strange art of the game. The art looks a litte odd, but overall it gets normal, and cartoonish and funny as well. Sure, its not your average realistic art, but as you venture deeper into the art, it really shapes the game as to what the gameplay is; which is traveling inside the minds of others and fixing their mental state, which appears to be either a compact, organized mind, as simple as a theatre, or even a twisty and odd, but amazingly humorous neighborhood.

Overall, this game I think deserves a 10/10 for me. This is one of the best games over the thousands I've ever played, including cross platform. Yes, I'm talking about one of the top games I've played compared to PlayStation consoles, Xbox consoles, handhelds, Nintendo consoles, iOS and Android, and desktop/PC/computer.

I've never in my life played a story in a game as good as this. My only regret of this game is beating it, as I don't know what to do now.......
And also for Notch to not fund a sequel to the game. Why Notch, WHY!!! It's only 18 million, thats 1/300 out of your pocket.

reviewText:
Absolutely incredible game.

Still able to be played today. After a while, you don't notice the aged graphics, because cartoony graphics age well.
Gameplay is great. Story is great. Characters are great.

Exploring is a blast as well, because the setting is unique... you play as a psychic child in a camp for other psychics. Reminds me of a few of my school camps.

This game comes from a time when games didn't have to be excessively violent to allow for great gameplay, and when singleplayer campaigns actually had some love and dedication put into them. There needs to be more games like this.

Well, what are you waiting for? Chuck your goggles on and embark on your journey to become a Psychonaut!

reviewText:
Psychonauts is a classic action/adventure platformer which follows the story of a young psychic named Raz. In his quest to join the Psychonauts - an elite group of international psychic secret agents--he breaks into their secret training facility: Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp. But this is no average psychic summer camp! A mysterious villain has kidnapped Raz’s fellow campers and stolen their brains. Now he must use his psychic powers of Telekinesis, Levitation, and most of all his ability to project himself into the minds of others--to find the loose noodles and keep them from falling into the wrong hands. Fight mental demons! Uncover hidden memories! Sort emotional baggage!

Psychonauts has a quite unique story and level design in addition to various kinds of psychic abilities. Raz's character is pretty well developed. He is perhaps the best voiced character in game. However the other characters are pretty dull and not quite well developed. They are pretty forgettable.

In terms of visuals Psychonauts is pretty decent with some pretty good art work complimented with some wonderful sound production which plays a huge part in the game. The level design is great and solving puzzles can be fun as every puzzle has something unique to offer

Pros:
- Stunning Visuals
- Wonderful sound production
- Voice Acting
- Save Anywhere
- Decent Puzzles

Cons:
- Troublesome Camera Controls
- Few blocky objects
- Forgettable Characters

reviewText: For all its imaginative flair, people are going to be put off by Psychonauts’ haphazard assembly; it has all the mechanical aspects of a product not quite completed, made by people not entirely sure what they were doing. At some point, the game decides you’ve spent enough time learning how it’s supposed to work and assumes you can effortlessly pull off a series of challenging jumps, or that you’ve mastered its fumbling combat system. You haven’t; of course you haven’t, and what follows is a chorus of curses and rage-quitting or, in the case of the poor saps trying to play this on a keyboard, uncontrollable rage. But for those who can work past these flaws, Psychonauts has traits that seem largely forgotten in today’s conveyer belt of annual sequels and follow-the-fad gameplay. It’s genuinely funny, for one and has just the right amount of surrealist endearment and adolescent awkwardness to make it completely unique. There’s nothing else out there quite like Psychonauts, where you can be fighting a lucha libre wrestling cat pretending to be an eagle in a neon pastel ring one moment, then be terrorising a city full of tiny lumpy fishmen as a Godzilla-sized monster the very next. Where you can be listening to a classmate tell you that his tin foil hat stops him accidently exploding faces or another one trying to sneak time on the camp radio to return to her home planet, because she feels this world is doomed.\n\nFull Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12430/pc/psychonauts/review.html

reviewText:
I missed Psychonaut when it first came out in 2006 and only heard about it a few years later. I only just recently finally decided to play it and I'm so glad I did. Psychonaut is an adventure platforming game with a great story and humor. Psychonaut are special people gifted with psychics abilities. You play the game as Raz, the new kid of a psychonaut summercamp.

What makes this game intersting is the variety of game mechanics that it introduces. As a psychonaut, you can enter into other people's mind. All the characters are very well designed and their levels are completly different. Even today, this game still looks really innovative.

Finally, the game really aged well. The graphics and gameplay are still very good. If you want to play one of the best games from the PS2/Xbox era, this is it.

reviewText: Older games tend to feel sluggish and slightly boring when you re-play them again, but I found that Psychonauts is still a very entertaining game. Its got lots of dark humor, fun gameplay, charming characters and it can get a little challenging sometimes. I recomend this game to any one looking for a hillarious adventure to play.\n\nOn a sidenote, this game is missing proper compatibility with the xbox 360 controller and the controls showed in dialogues are only those of the keyboard. The good news is that there is a free patch that fixes both of these things, PsychoPadLite by voodooman. I highly recommend it as this game doesnt feel half as excellent without the feel of a controller.

reviewText:
I finally got the chance to buy it and finish it.
I played it as a kid and I loved it!

Not much has changed now, many years later.
It's still unique to me, it's still amazing, you have to be talented to create something like that, to imagine something like those worlds and to make that idea work out perfect.

I really want to see Psychonauts 2.  I really, really do, so many years later this amazing game deserves matching sequel, I could only imagine that it would be so much better and so popular in sea of copy paste games that are surrounding us today.

However if you are completely new, you should know that Psychonauts is one of those games that you should play because they are so unique and amazing in many ways. Just the game quallity is over the top for period it was released in, you can see on almost everything that hours of hard work and passion were put in it, to look amazing.

So many puzzles, worlds, interesting stories, so many unique things and possibilities, things to see and things to do.

I loved every segment of those, just like I did before...

reviewText:
Psychonauts : โครตพลังจิตป่วนหัวคนบ้า

(7/10 B++)

ก่อนจะมี brutal legends เรามี Psychonauts เป็นความสำเร็จหลักของ Double Fine  ผมจำได้ว่า ได้เห็นเกมนี้ครั้งแรกทางช่อง G4 ที่ true เอามาฉายตอนนั้น มันมาเป็นรายการสารคดีของตัวเกม Psychonauts ที่ฉายให้เห็นถึงช่วงเวลา 1 อาทิตย์สุดท้ายก่อนเกมจะวางขาย ผมได้ฟังสิ่งที่ผู้พัฒนาเกม บอกถึงความน่าสนใขของตัวเกม แล้วผมชอบแนวคิดของเกมมาก ที่ว่าด้วยเรื่องการเข้าไปในจิตใจของคนอื่น บวกกับค่ายที่ฝึกสอนสายลับผู้มีพลังจิต(เหมือนลอก XMEN มาเลย)
ตัวเกมจะเป็นแนวกึ่งเดินตะลุยกึ่ง open world เกมค่อนข้างที่จะมีอิสระให้เราไปไหนมาไหน แต่ก็จะบังคับให้เราทำภารกิจหลักตลอด(สมัยนั้น เกม open world ยังไม่บูมมาก) โดยเฉพาะการเข้าไปในหัวของคนอื่น ซึ่งผมว่ามันเจ๋งมาก เหมือนเราได้เห็นโลกที่อยู่ในหัวของคนๆหนึ่ง (เหมือนหนังเรื่อง being john malkovich ) ตัวเกมจะสลับกับระหว่างโลกจริงกับโลกในจิตใจไปๆมาๆ โดยจุดหมายของเกมคือการแก้ปัญหาทางสภาพจิตใจในหัวของคนอื่นไปเรื่อยๆ
การออกแบบตัวละครกับโลกในเกมดูคล้ายๆหลุดออกมาจากหนังของ tim burton

ระบบการเล่น : ตัวเกมจะเป็นแนวเดินตะลุยแก้ปริศษาไปตามทาง เดินๆย้อนไปย้อนมาบ้าง หลังๆมันจะคล้ายๆกับ mario 64 มาก
ระบบการต่อสู้ผมว่ามันทำออกมาไม่ค่อยมีดี เพราะส่วนใหญ่เกมมันจะเน้นให้คุยเยอะ การต่อสู้ระหว่างทางมันเลยทำให้ดูน่าเบื่อตลอดทั้งเกม แต่กลับกันผมกลับชอบการสู้บอส ของเกมนี้มาก ทั้งสนุกบวกฮา การสู้กับบอสดูจะให้เราใช้สมองอยู่พอตัว ก็ตามแบบฉบับเกมสมัยก่อนที่วิธีการกำจัดบอสนั้นมีวิธีของมัน ไม่ใช้ฟัดๆหลับๆอย่างเดียว

ภาพ : จัดอยู่ในระดับกลาง เป็นภาพการ์ตูนที่ดูไม่สวยอะไรมาก แต่บอกตามตรงเห็นครั้งผมนึกถึงหนังของ tim burton โครต ทั้งการออกแบบตัวละคร การออกแบบโลกในหัวคนอื่นหรือแม้กระทั้งเพลงประกอบ

ข้อเสีย : -เกมมี bugs ให้เห็รอยู่บางส่วน โดยเฉพาะ พวก bugs ติดกำแพง ติดบันไดบาง

สรุป : ผมว่าเกมนี้ทำออกมาค่อนข้างดีเลยนะ ถึงมันจะเป็นแค่เกมเด็กเล่น ที่เล่นข้ามเวลาแล้วตัวเกมก็ไม่ได้ยาวอะไร ผมเล่นแล้วก็เพลินๆดี ผ่านไปได้ แต่มันก็มีบางจุดเหมือนกันที่มันน่าเบื่อ เช่น ฉากที่เราจะต้อง เดินเข้าตัวตึก แล้วมีใยแมงมุมขวางประตู เราต้องใช้เงินจำนวนหนึ่้งไปซื้อเครื่องกำจัดใย แล้วเกมก็จะบังคับเราให้ไปซื้อไอ้เครื่องนั้นอย่างเดียว ซึ่งผมว่ามันน่าเบื่อโครต เพราะเราต้องมานั่งเสียเวลาเก็บใบไม้ม่วงเฮงซวยที่ใช้แทนค่าเงิน เพื่อไปซื้อเครื่องกำจัดใย แล้วใช้มันผ่านประตูแค่ครั้งเดียวของเกม

reviewText: Simply a must-try, to my view. Rare is the sort of mental physique Psychonauts flexes in its deliciously captivating stages; rarer still is the sort of video game that joins such eccentric design to a bevy of wildly fun tricks and gadgets available for probing and prodding its velveteen landscapes. Fluid platforming through all three dimensions builds but the theater in which these fascinating loons unfurl their scripted pandemonium. From the unbound depths of a whispered mutant lurker and a stout facsimile emperor to the hypersurreal reaches of an acrobatic butcher and a Milk-and-road-crew neighborhood, the plucky and precocious Raz maketh his way to the finale: A rendezvous...with the mind. You wanna come along~?

reviewText:
I just finished my first playthrough of this game 7 and a half years after its release.  It's a very strange game to be sure.  It is a very unique concept playing a child who is training to be a psychic warrior, battling monsters inside other people's minds.  The game is very well written and despite being so stylized, the characters are quite realistic (though a few of them are fairly annoying.)  It also still manages to be quite humorous despite its age.

The game's setting at a kids' summer camp and the art style lead me to believe the game is aimed at kids, yet the subject matter is a bit more mature.  I think the game would be much too difficult for children as well.  It's a bit confusing for me.

Now Double Fine was nice enough to update the game for Steam after many years which I greatly appreciate.  After putting in that effort though, I'd think they would have fixed some of the outstanding bugs.  I ran into quite a few ladders with broken dismounts at the top (one was so bad it took me about 10 tries each time to get off the ladder at the top and I had to climb it 10+ times) and a few other level glitches.  There are quite a few really badly placed fixed camera angles throughout the game.  The smart camera" won't turn off despite changing the setting so the keyboard/mouse controls as essentially unusable.  I highly recommend downloading a mod called PsychoPad which gives you a modern gamepad layout with proper button prompts for the standard 360 controller (something else I think Double Fine should've taken care of.)

Overall a very enjoyable game
date: though I wouldn't go so far as to call it a classic like many people do."

reviewText:
Go here to support PSYCHONAUTS 2:
https://www.fig.co/campaigns/psychonauts-2

YES, it is as real as the air you breath.

The actual review:

Ever get to a game so late that it came out 2 generations ago?

Well that was me this year when I finally played Psychonauts. Ironically, I had already owned this game TWICE and never gotten around to playing it. I'm a firm believer that disappointment is always the prelude to something much better. My 21 hours with Psyhonauts was proof enough for me because I know had I played it on when I owned it for the original Xbox(or the atrocious looking port that slipped it's way on the PSN store) I would have not have likely enjoyed it as much as the PC version.

You play a young boy named Razputin(Raz for short) who sneaks his way into a summer camp specifically for kids with psychic abilities. You start off with some basic braining" missions to get your feet wet only to find out there's a secret plot to take over the world being hatched under everyone's noses.

The visual presentation is something I immediately noticed when I booted up this game. My laptop has some fairly decent specs. Since this was already an older game I naturally turned all the settings to max(the game allows for full HD display at 1920 x1080 pixels
date: btw) and was literally blown away. Characters and environments(though somewhat dated looking)were sharp and clean
recommended: on-screen colors were vibrant and lively and textures(especially on Raz and some level segments) were highly detailed. Couple that with the game consistently running at a solid 60 fps and you have quite the throwback here if you never experienced it before like I did.\n\nThe overall gameplay doesn't do much to reinvent the wheel but the controls are solid and most of Raz's abilities are fairly unique in comparison to most other platformers. In short you're getting a game that shines more through it's delivery of quirky worlds
hoursPlayed: clever level design and and a bizarre yet highly memorable story.\n\nThe characters are fun and some even hilarious
voteText: the music is practically an orchestral masterpiece and every single level has a unique flavor that will stick in your head even after you've finished. My favorite without a doubt was Black Velvetopia with it's high contrasting neon colors
helpfulPercent: clever symbolism and absolutely badass theme music that all came together making me think "Mexican TRON Laser Tag".\n\nThis game is by no means a staple in gameplay standards or mechanics
votesHelpful: but it doesn't have to be to succeed as well as it does. It's colorful
votesTotal:
charismatic and so well thought out. Everything from story to gemeplay and sound design is executed on a level that many games of today aren't even achieving.

The last 10 years of game releases has been missing the kind of flavor that Psychonauts brings to the table. Creativity has been mostly been traded for "sellability" and unique and original concepts like these are almost non-existent in most AAA titles.

If I had one(and ONLY one) real complaint with this game it's that the rendered cutscenes look like absolute ♥♥♥♥ compared to the game itself. Had they rerendered them in higher quality or just did something to imprive their appearance this game might be damn near perfect as it stands.

This is seriously one crazy cool game. BUY THIS GAME.

Support funding for Psychonauts 2 so we can get a sequel!

https://www.fig.co/campaigns/psychonauts-2"

reviewText:
For people who hate reviews and want a super-condensed summary: Great game, buy it.  Memorable characters, timeless art design, great story, solid platforming.  Soundtrack's great as well, it runs on pretty much anything, get hyped for Psychonauts 2.

Psychonauts doesn't look impressive judging by Steam's front cover, but store pages could never be more deceiving.  Psychonauts is definitely a must-have, that much is clear.  Excellent writing and level design make for an overall memorable game with plenty of secrets and lore to find on your own.  The story is very well-done and definitely grabs you within the first hour.  Not only this, but the choice of odd, cartoonish characters make the art style rather timeless despite being an Xbox Original.

Updated to be compatible with all modern platforms and with the excellent soundtrack for sale, you definitely need to get this one.  I'd talk about cons, but other than the occasional time getting lost (especially with Waterloo and the camp hubworld), I've got nothing bad to say.  Besides, let's face it, Psychonauts 2 is probably going to be excellent, so why not prepare for it?
--
Oh, and one last note: For a low-end PC, this game's got you covered.  I was able to play through it on a Pentium E6600 and Intel GMA... even running on something that can't handle FEAR at 12 FPS is impressive, but it was fully playable at 800x600 with this extreme example of outdated hardware.  With Intel HD, 720p with a special effect won't be in the slightest a problem, and with a low-end GPU like the GT 620, it'll run perfectly at 1080p60.  With this little discussion on the hardware required now dealt with, you have no excuse to play it.

reviewText:
Hands down the best game I have played in years and most definitely one of my favorite games ever.

The story is simply amazing and I love it so much. The visuals are cartoony that simply do not age. It looked great back in the day, it looks great now, and I believe it will continue to look great in the future. It's amazing! The models do show their age with the polygon counts but it just works great alongside the painted textures and actually adds to the atmosphere of the game.

The gameplay was unlike anything I've ever played before. It plays like a third person shooter with the psychic powers but somehow it feels so different. I can't quite put my finger on it. There is also a lot of fun platforming and some puzzle solving as well as thousands of little things to collect for points and concept art!

The atmosphere of this game is simply the best I've ever experienced. The look and feel of the game really suck you into the story and world. I absolutely love it. I don't recall the music being very prominent in-game but I absolutely love listening to the soundtrack on it's own.

The game may be old but it holds up very well. It took me 13 hours to beat and I didn't obsess over every little thing to gather. And there is a lot of stuff to find.

reviewText:
I'm gonna be honest with you my first impressions of this legendary game were not that good at all.

Erratic camera controls, clunky platforming and I'm sure it wouldn't have been a difficult task for the guys at Double Fine to include some controller button icons instead of the keyboard keys for us controller users (there are some unofficial patches online but they don't always work).

However I decided to stick with it and boy was I rewarded.

Plain words cannot describe Tim Schafer's and his team's brilliance. If you are looking for a genuinely humorous game exprerience you are not going to be dissapointed. Every mission, every string of dialogue has been carefully woven into this truly original concept of mind exploration and makes it well worth your time. The gameplay may be uninteresting to most, but what this game manages to show is that each and every game is an emptry canvas waiting to be filled not only by innovation but also by creativity.

reviewText: I love platformers so it's hard for me to understand how I have overlooked Psychonaughts for almost 10 years. Psychonaughts is just an all around great game. Sure you may encounter a glitch or 2 and some parts are frustrating because of how lock-on the controls are but those minor annoyances hardly brings down the overall experience. The dialogue is weird and hilarious at the same time and for me it's some of the best I have experienced in a game. Took about 20 hours to fully complete and get all the achievements. If you are a completionist i'd recommend googling the missable achievements just so you are aware of where and when to get them. Anyways, the game is well worth the 10 dollar price point and one can only hope a sequel will eventually get made.

reviewText:
As with many old classics, this game does not seem to have aged gracefully.
The controls are clunky and often painful, and many of the puzzles punish you for creativity and have solutions that can seem counter intuitive.
However, this game sits well amongst the most fun 3D platformers that I have played.
The early levels, before you get too many psi skills, are extremely rewarding and fun, and the characters are endearing and wonderful. You do not need to spend long in this game to fall in love with it, but, if you spend too long in the game, the controls may drive you mad.

[EDIT]
Upon further inspection (i.e. playing through the last two levels) I have changed my mind. This game is pure punishment.
I am a level headed person, but, by-jove, do I want to put my fist through my computer screen right now.
The game design as the game draws to a close is so poor that it makes you wonder whether they actually tested the last few levels.

In the penultimate level, you are climbing a precarious tower, with all the possibility of falling right to the start at any point, and the enemies are swarming rats. Now, this is not a bad point, but the fact the rats explode, leave a mist of confusion in their wake, turning all your controls around and also mirroring your screen, whilst doing nearly three points of damage each as well, is crazy.
With the narrow paths that you are taking at this point, you cannot kite the rats, and with the horrible camera controls, you can rarely see them, meaning you cannot target the rats with your psi-beams. Melee attacks cause them to explode anyways, so you’re screwed.
If you get hit by one of these rats, you get hit by all of them.
Should you survive a wave of rats, they are infinitely respawning. So when you inevitably fall, or reach the next set of rats, you will get attacked again, and die.

That’s not even the part that got me most wound up, though.
I worked through the god awful controls; the input lag; the counter-intuitive puzzles; the unresponsive scenery; the hideous camera control; the inaccurate, floaty jumping; the infinite spawning enemies, all the stuff that comes with old, out-dated games. The thing that really got me was the last level. It’s a bloody escort quest!
Now let that sink in. An escort quest on a 3D platformer, where you have to protect an NPC from infinitely spawning enemies. It does not end there.
The NPC jumps ahead of you, and in order to protect him, you must platform over to him, completing puzzles as he gets attacked.
One of these puzzles is baiting knife throwers into hitting a rotating target-board, so you can grab the knife and then swing and jump onto the platform. They have a wind up, and a reload animation, and most of the time you won’t be able to grab the knife automatically.
So, whilst the NPC is getting wailed on by three evil bunny rabbits, you are waiting for the perfect knife throw, just so you can go round the board, only to realise that the jump at the top of the board requires you to leave at the perfect angle and move in the air despite the camera swinging around mid-jump. Queue plummeting to the start of the level. Queue the NPC dying and the level restarting. Queue my fist through my laptop screen.

Save yourself a lot of hassle with this game. Find a YouTube play-through of the game with good commentary and relax.
Buy this game at your peril.

TL;DR - This game is like pulling teeth. Whether it's story line makes it worth it is debateable.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Psychonauts is a great game. The story is tight, and everything comes together seemlessly. I love the art and the soundtrack, and the characters have... well, character. Every time I play this game I find out something new. There are lots of hidden rooms, extra cutscenes, and little tidbits of information that you pick up each time. It's such a well-built world filled with character. I'm a writer by trade, and I love all of the ironic moments and plays-on-words. This game has what can only be described as charm.

The gameplay is great (I've played on the Xbox and the PC). Fighting is easy enough for those of you who aren't hardcore gamers, but it's still challenging and strategic, so it doesn't get boring.

Psychonauts is my favorite game of all time. I've finished it 100% several times, and it never gets old.

reviewText:
Really enjoyed this game. It's a platformer in the same mold as games like Spyro or Ratchet and Clank and manages to be a lot of fun. The level design is amazing with some really entertaining and original levels, for example theres one level where you find yourself as a giant in a city  populated by fishmen and you have to rampage through it like Godzilla.

There's a lot to do in this game as well with lots of collectibles and different powers to unlock so theres plenty reason to explore the different levels and areas and there's a good 15-20 hours of gameplay if your looking to do everything.

The only downsides are that the graphics look quite dated and the camera angles canbe a bit awkward at times but not enough to impact on enjoyment of the game. Also while the game is probably better played with a controller the Xbox controller symbols haven't been added so it's a case of figuring out for yourself which buttons do what.Again this isn't a major issue.

Overall this is a really fun game thats really worth playing. It's a 8/10 for me.

reviewText: A fantastic PS2 style adventure with lots of charm. I wish I would have played this back when its 3D was cutting edge, but it still holds up well enough thanks to the cartoony nature and Tim Burton-esque character and environment design. Following weird kids studying military combat at a psychic summer camp built on an indian burial ground (do you capitalize Indian" when it's not technically the correct word to use?) the whole world is wonderfully warped and twisted
date: each drunken tree home to birds that explode from the power of your mind. And yes...the tin foil hat is an actual item. You don't have to play Psychonauts with a controller
recommended: but you'll probably prefer it if you have one to plug in. The gameplay itself is nothing groundbreaking
hoursPlayed: but the "flavor text" spin of the steps is very refreshing. This game was a steal at $5."

reviewText: Incredibly memorable game. I first played it back in 2008 on the original Xbox and while I haven't yet completed it on steam, I still think it's one of the best single-player games I've ever played. Fantastic story, memorable characters, unique and fantastical art style and excellent controls (which are an essential for a platformer) all lend themselves to create an incredibly satisfying and fun game. (Highly recommend a controller!)

reviewText: When I was getting this game in a pack with another nice one, I wasn't even sure if it was that good. The trailer and screenshots didn't work that well on me and I mostly wanted it for the other game in the pack. And yet... I played this and... Whoa... This game is a masterpiece! It's a very entertaining game, without voilence, so good for all ages and those who simply don't enjoy killing. Also for those who normally do like bloodshed, I still think you'd find a refreshing change playing this. What genre is it? Hard to say. Kinda platformish, kinda RPG-ish. You control a boy learning to become a psychonaut, travelling in people's minds, where you jump around avoiding the dangers, collecting figments and sorting emotional baggage. You level up as you progress, which is why I say it's RPG-ish a bit too. It also contains a great story with lots of cutscenes, some minigames and it's extremely colourful and pleasant. I love it.

reviewText: It is no small task for any developer to craft a game that appeals to both the 'hardcorest' of hardcore gamers and casual players alike, but that is exactly what Double Fine has done with Psychonauts. An epic masterpiece on pretty much all levels, Psychonauts has it all. Platforming, exploration, collectibles, crafting, and of course - an absolutely ZANY world full of loveable characters (and not so 'loveable') set in a vast mostly open world that brings back childhood memories in bucketfulls of mischievious gaming bliss.\n\nAn absolutely superb game that has no equal = 9.5/10  (.5 taken off for camera 'weirdness' at times) = a MUST have and a MUST play!!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Colourful, funny and solid gameplay. Never played this on the original xbox, so there are no rose tinted glasses here. This game holds up very well for its age. When old games are hyped up a lot, I'm always skeptical, nostalgia is a powerful thing.
But this game absolutely lives up to the hype around it, and deserves its cult following.

I really enjoyed this game, and would highly recommend it to anyone!
